Hollow Knight is an incredible game.

When I first bought it, I wasn't sure whether I'd like it. I had never played any metroidvania before, never even any game featuring proper platforming!  I was far from good at the game, but it was just so captivating that any time I failed, I had no intent to give up. I still remember fighting [spoiler]Hornet for the first time[/spoiler]. That was the moment I fell in love with the game.

The combat is just so much fun. It never gets boring (as you can see by my playtime...). The music is wonderful. I haven't kept count of how many hours I've spent just listening to the soundtrack, but it's definitely quite a lot. 

I have never challenged myself in any game as much as in this one. I think beating [spoiler]Path of Pain[/spoiler] is where it all started. First that, then suddenly it was [spoiler]radiant Hall of Gods, radiant Hall of Gods again? Then the third time...? Look, beating bosses hitless is a lot of fun. And then, my greatest accomplishment, which took me almost half a year - Panteon of Hallownest with all bindings at once. It was a painful process, but I don't regret a single minute of it.[/spoiler]

To sum it up - the game is a ton of fun. It has a lot of content and is ABSOLUTELY worth the price. Now that Silksong is out... I will still be coming back to Hollow Knight from time to time. As amazing as the sequel is, Hollow Knight will forever stay in my heart, just now with Silksong alongside it. Thank you Team Cherry for this masterpiece <3

A must play for any who enjoy metroidvanias -- abilities look cool and are fun to use alongside the combat feeling so smooth to adjust to and it shines especially bright during boss-fights, making it seem almost like a dance of attacks. 
There are multiple endings you can obtain, lots of things to collect, a multitude of bosses and enemies, and plenty of optional content to give you a challenge; oh yeah, challenge, this game is hard, if you don't like that, don't play. 
Hollow Knight does NOT hold your hand so you may get mad at times. Things are shown rather than told most of the time

Not to mention, the OST is absolutely beautiful and so is the art direction, you can really see it in the world building, the story was quite interesting to experience. I found myself getting really captured by this game's atmosphere and multiple times would I get distracted by something interesting while I was going to do something else.

Please give Hollow Knight a try and don't just give up on the game in the first few hours, the pace can be a bit slow at first but I promise you it gets so so so much better.

I feel it is my moral and legal obligation to file this public statement about Hollow Knight. Not about the gameplay, which is excellent, or the art, which is stunning, or the music, which is so good it briefly made me forgive a sentient maggot for consuming its weight in mystery goo. No. I am here to talk about something far more alarming.

The Grubfather is an unmitigated disaster of a parent.

Let us begin with the setting. Hallownest is a labyrinth of OSHA violations so severe they belong in textbooks under the heading "How to Fail at Civilization." There are:

1. Bottomless pits with no railings
2. Spikes stored in quantities appropriate for medieval torture museums
3. Platforms that move, crumble, or explode depending on their emotional state
4. Acid pools placed directly beneath common walkways
5. Elevators that operate under the guiding principle of "hope nothing is underneath"

And in the middle of this carnival of workplace safety nightmares, the Grubfather decides that the best place for his hundreds of extremely fragile larva children is scattered randomly across the kingdom like collectible trading cards.

These grubs are not even hidden in safe places. They are shoved into the walls of spider dens, tucked behind warriors who fight like caffeinated wasps, or placed in jars right next to explosive creatures that sneeze napalm. If you pitched this childcare strategy to any responsible adult they would call the guards.

The Knight, an unpaid intern by all appearances, is the only one doing anything about it. This tiny bug-paladin is the sole employee of Hallownest Child Protective Services. Every rescued grub cheers with pure joy. It is heartwarming. It is also damning. These children have clearly never experienced consistent care, supervision, or even a moderately secure storage solution.

And what does the Grubfather do when you bring his kids back? He sits there slurping, showering you with pocket change like a grandfather who forgot Christmas, occasionally coughing up trinkets of questionable origin. I have seen vending machines with more emotional range.

As more grubs return, the noises coming from his house grow louder. I will not attempt to categorize these noises. My therapist insists we avoid using the word "eating," but if it wiggles like a grub and sounds like a blender filled with pudding, I reserve the right to raise an eyebrow.

Hollow Knight is incredible. It is one of the best games I have ever played. But let the record show that the Grubfather is either the worst parent in recorded history or a creature who treats parenthood like a gacha mechanic. In any functional kingdom, he would already be on several watchlists.

Still five stars. The grub rescues alone are worth every minute.

Would I recommend the game? Absolutely.
Would I recommend leaving children with the Grubfather? Only if you enjoy weekend-long expeditions through OSHA‚Äôs personal vision of purgatory.

Hollow Knight is a game that speaks to one‚Äôs heart.

It makes you rage, it makes you feel like you have lead fingers, and it makes you want to give up everything at once.
But it pulls you back, again, and again, and again.

I only have 40 hours in the game so far, in the past 2 weeks, that‚Äôs how much I‚Äôve logged, but the lore, the emotions, the story have all hit me like a truck, even if I haven‚Äôt yet finished it. Thank God I avoided all media of Hollow Knight, because it makes my playthrough so much more enjoyable.

Now, let‚Äôs talk about some moments that really spoke to me.

When I first took out the False Knight, I felt a wave of joy in my soul. I was genuinely happy for taking out a worm.
When I fought Hornet, I raged so much because of her fast attacks and my greediness that it helped me learn to be patient.
When I finally beat the Mantis Lords after like 5 attempts, I was happy that I could figure out how to read patterns and play to them.
When I came back to Myla after the Soul Sanctum, I uh, I broke a bit, to be honest. The only thing I wish I could do is have an item to stop it before it‚Äôs too late for our singing bug.
When it all turned orange (which is where I am right now) I realized I need to hurry up and clean out the attic.

Hollow Knight is a game that makes you feel so much emotion, so much joy, pain, and happiness, that it feels unreal.

I genuinely thank Team Cherry for this game, and I can‚Äôt wait to finish it by dancing with a moth (whatever that means, courtesy of a friend, @LoopaDoop).

I just completed my first playthrough and I now realize why this game has been recommended to me for years.

Pros:
-Combat is so fluid
-Boss battles are fun and can be learned (except for a couple that NEED certain charms/powerups)
-Asymmetrical Story Line (fun, but also a con)
-Music is phenomenal
-Artwork is pheonmenal
-Regular enemies are easy to understand
-No "hand holding"
-VERY challenginging

Cons:
-Assymetrical Story Line (I got lost and didn't know where to go/what I needed in some parts)
-The start is a slog, but gets really fun once you get some abilities
-Some 'dialogue' is annoying

I didn't enjoy the game in the beginning. The story is super convoluted and I needed a lot of Lore videos to understand what I just played. The story is not easily told, or understood. The limited abilities/movement in the beginning had me very, very confused, but once we got about 10 hours, or so, into the game. I was quickly addicted and couldn't get away. 
I used the 5 days I had off of work to "beat" this game for the first time, and do not regret it at all!
Overall, I give this game a high 9/10 or 10/10. I had a great time with this game and only completed it with 69%. (no joke, couldn't make that sh** up) Some things got very difficult, and having no direction can get confusing, but when things click and you remember things you can traverse that you couldn't in your first hours, the games starts coming together quickly. 

With that done...I can now go try to 112% the game.

My hands began to shake. My heart hammered against my ribs. Hit after hit, dodge after dodge‚Äîa desperate dance ascending into the cosmos during that final, brutal climb. I pushed onward, scaling the peak of existence itself to claim my rightful place in the Hall of Gods.

That was more than a victory; it was one of the most unforgettable experiences of my life. A perfect game, forever occupying a sacred chamber of my heart.

Hollow Knight is one of those rare games that feels alive: not just in its world, but in the quiet emotion woven into every corner of Hallownest. The hand-drawn art, haunting music, and subtle storytelling create an atmosphere that stays with you long after you stop playing. Every area feels like a piece of a fallen kingdom still whispering its history, and exploring it is equal parts beautiful and melancholic. The combat and movement are tight, precise, and deeply rewarding. Progress isn‚Äôt handed to you, you earn it, step by step, room by room, sometimes triumphantly and sometimes stubbornly. Yet that struggle makes every breakthrough feel genuine. The game trusts the player, and in doing so, creates a bond rarely seen in modern titles. What truly sets Hollow Knight apart is the emotional journey: the loneliness, the perseverance, and the strange warmth found in unexpected places and characters. It‚Äôs a game that doesn‚Äôt need to shout; it speaks softly, and that‚Äôs what makes it powerful.
A masterpiece of atmosphere, design, and quiet storytelling. Hollow Knight isn‚Äôt just played, it‚Äôs felt.

[h1] Score: ‚óÜ‚óÜ‚óÜ‚óÜ‚óÜ (5/5) [/h1] 

TLDR: An unforgettable experience and a must play for metroidvania fans and newcomers alike.

I understand. I finally understand why this game has the fan base it does and why Hollowsong hype reached unbelievable levels leading up to release. Hollow Knight is a journey that tested my perseverance at multiple points, sometimes edging close to me questioning if I should throw in the towel. HK kept me enthralled with its incredible world building and the deep satisfaction earned by overcoming whatever roadblock I was stuck on. Admittedly my history with metroidvanias is very limited, but I'm eager to dive deeper into the genre after this.

HK wastes zero time getting you into the game, a theme that was persistent throughout my 45 hour playthrough. It rarely takes control away from the player and when it does, it does so briefly and for good reason. The story and world are there for you to engage with at whatever level you desire. There is a lot of interesting lore and backstory to Hallownest, the ruined subterranean kingdom you explore. What HK does even better is its character, enemy, and boss design. There are literally over 100 enemy types, each with unique and interesting designs. The bosses are simply a delight to fight thanks to their presentation, creative move sets, and of course, the music. When the Dung Defender first dives onto the screen I could not contain the huge grin on my face. Other bosses like Soul Master and the Mantis Lords are excellent examples of showing rather than telling when it comes to defining a character's personality.

The world of Hollow Knight is the true star of the show and is incredibly addicting to gradually explore as you unlock more abilities in typical metroidvania fashion. I was originally worried about environmental diversity given the game takes place underground for almost the entire duration, but the developers do an excellent job mixing things up. Biomes feel unique but also fitting and sensible whether you are in typical rocky caverns, crystalline tunnels, a literal underground city, dense jungles, or more. You have to purchase each biome's map from an NPC in a specific location in that biome. This map gives you a basic layout, but requires further exploration if you want a complete map. I think this is great, although I am less of a fan of the map not updating until you sit at a bench. I could also take or leave the fact that you cannot see yourself on the map unless you use up a charm notch, but it is not the end of the world.

Okay, the combat is also the star of the show. What can I say, this show has a lot of stars. Hollow Knight's moveset is initially very simple since you are left with basically just a nail to swing, a heal, and the ability to move and jump. That is literally it, but as expected with the genre, you will gain abilities as you explore such as a dash that can be upgraded to allow traversal or even damage, spells, special nail attacks, and more. Techniques such as pogoing, in which you use the momentum from striking downwards on an enemy below you to keep yourself in the air, further add to the game's depth. Beyond that you have charms which, when equipped, give special bonuses or even abilities. Charms have a notch value and you are limited in how many charms you can equip by the number of notches you have, although this can be upgraded. This forces you to make decisions about which charms to use and it is common for different setups to work best for different bosses. All of this comes together when you are engaged in boss fights with arenas and tactics that test your aptitude as the Hollow Knight.

The music is unsurprisingly fantastic, but the sound design, especially for the enemies and NPCs, is really creative. Entombed Husks and Flukemons are particularly notable for how disgusting they sound, perfectly fitting for where and what they are. The only things I found lacking were a few platforming sections and some annoying enemies, usually of the flying variety. I think flying enemies as a baseline tend to be a nuisance, but certain ones like Primal Aspids and Crystal Hunters take this up a notch while also being found in tougher platforming sections.

These moments are fleeting and increasingly rare as you, the Hollow Knight, become stronger. By the end of my playthrough I felt nearly unstoppable outside of the most challenging boss fights. This game came a long way from its beginning as a game jam project on Newgrounds, which was considered a bad game at the time. I am going to let a little time pass before I dig into Silksong, but I am very excited for my next taste of Team Cherry.

[h1]THE BEST METROIDVANIA GAME[/h1]

It‚Äôs the [b]hardest game[/b] I‚Äôve ever played. For an [b]indie title created[/b] by only [b]three people[/b], it‚Äôs truly [b]marvelous[/b]. Nobody could have imagined a game like this before it was completed. The combat is tight and responsive, making every encounter feel fair even when it‚Äôs brutally challenging. However, I can't finish this game [b]due to the difficulty[/b].

The [b]sound design and music contribute[/b] so much to the overall experience. Subtle ambient sounds make the world feel alive, while the soundtrack enhances both quiet moments and intense battles. It successfully added so much [b]emotion and tension[/b] to me.

Despite its difficulty, the game never stops being rewarding. [i]Hollow Knight[/i] proves how far creativity and passion can go, even with a small team. It remains one of the [b]most polished and immersive indie games[/b] ever made, and the [b]level of care[/b] put into every detail is [b]truly remarkable[/b].

Honestly, does this game even need an introduction? its an awesome game made by 3 Ausies with pure love and joy, like what more could you ask for?

Its a metroidvania and a good one at that. There is constant backtracking, which some people might find annoying, but it only makes it all the more rewarding if you actually remeber where youre supposed to go.

The fights are very challenging, but not too hard eighter. If youre expecting dark souls level bosses, then you might be slightly dissapointed, as it wont take you hundreds upon hundreds of attempts, but youre not gonna beat them on your first try eighter. Very well balanced if you ask me.

The fighting system is good, as its not just the same thing over and over again. There are many different bosses, but also many different spells that you collect throughout the whole game, so you dont get overwhelmed at the start, but your options expand over time (then again, most people dont use them unless its requiered).

What this game excels at however, is the movement system. Similarly to the fighting system, you acuire new mechanics as you progress and it even makes the fighting in the game feel way better when you know how to use each move.

Overall, i couldnt recommend this game enough. I think everyone should try it at least once. A lot of people lose interest before they even get to greenpath (second main area), which is a real shame, but if it really doesnt entice you enough to keep playing, then maybe metroidvanias arent for you. And thats fine. Just please dont clown on a good game because you dont have what it takes to play it.

I haven‚Äôt fully finished the game yet, but I‚Äôm at about 96 percent. This review is mostly for players who are trying to decide whether to get Silksong or Hollow Knight first.

I recommend starting with the first Hollow Knight because Silksong is a bit harder. Learning the basic mechanics in the first game will help a lot before getting into Silksong.

One nice thing about Silksong is that it has no DLCs yet, so going for full completion feels more straightforward. In Hollow Knight, there is the main 100 percent game and then three extra DLCs. If you like to play without guides or spoilers, those DLCs can be harder to find and complete.

Basically, try the first Hollow Knight before Silksong. It will make the experience smoother and more enjoyable.

Other than that, I personally loved this game even if it was a bit of a challenge. Would recommend!

I was originally gonna write about this game's minor flaws, and then say that it must be doing something right, because I enjoyed it nontheless.
But why write about a game's flaws in a positive review?

So, let me get something straight: I came to Hollow Knight with high expectations (it was my friends favorite game before the sequel released) and it DID NOT dissapoint.
Hollow Knight is a brilliantly crafted metroidvania. The biomes are really fun to explore with little trinkets hidden around every corner. Every ability that you get feels like it really improves your movement/combat.

The bosses are very unique and certainly have a different style than in most other games. I think they flow nicely though.

The game has charms which allow you for near-endless customisation of your abilities to suit your playstyle.

The music is also great, with the best biome tracks being [spoiler] Crystal Peak, Soul Sanctum and City of Tears [/spoiler]
and my favorite boss tracks were [spoiler] Hornet, Mantis Lords, Sealed Vessel and The Grimm Troupe [/spoiler].

The story is fascinating, but you'll probably need to watch a youtube video to understand it. I'll admit it's not told that well.

What else is there to say... the game is really pretty, that's for sure.

Oh yeah, Hollow Knight has several endings, plantly of achievements and side quests, so I wouldn't worry about replayability.

Yeah, in conclusion, it's a great game which I really enjoyed. hollow knight was a great game. at first i didnt like the dark atmosphere but it didnt turn out to be that bad, especially with areas like green pass. exploring was great, i enjoyed going into every nook and cranny and marking areas that i couldnt go to. it was very satisfying to finally get abilities that would allow you to go to certain areas that were blocked off before, so i could explore even more places. this game actually made me feel really good and "safe". it was the first game in a while i actually felt like i was resting while playing. ive still got silksong and im sure ill play that sometime. i like 100%ing games but call me a coward because i am not completing the game in under 10 hours. not to mention under 5 hours. i am not beating the game in permadeath mode. i am not beating the game in permadeath mode with 100% completion. i am not beating the game with 100% completion under 20 hours. ill try to get whatever achievements i can but other than that i already beat the witcher 2 on permadeath it was bad enough i dont want to make myself suffer with this game.

one more thing that really surprised me in the game was in deepnest. you have bugs crawling out of the ground, massive centipedes walking along their paths, you descend and descend. everything wants to kill you. eventually, you make it across one big hole. you dont know whats at the bottom. you cant see, its very deep. you take a plunge into the unknown, ready to slay the beasts that stand in your way... instead what greets you is a peaceful respite. a hot spring, a bench, a safe place to rest. a comfy little checkpoint before moving on deeper into the horrors of the deepnest.

This game is incredible. The story is rich, beautiful and deep. The world is immersive and full of variety, and each area has its own lore and story. The combat is smooth yet precise, and the bosses are so fun to fight. It is pretty difficult to get into, but it's really enjoyable to get into a flowstate while fighting the bosses, or to explore the vast areas this world has to offer. The soundtrack by Christopher Larkin is impeccable. I can say so many good things about this game, but I'd be spoiling the experience for you. Play the game. It's so cheap. Play the game.

The game is amazing, it pretty much has got everything. And the more I get familiar with the game the more I wanna play it. In the beginning, when I was getting used to the mechanics of the game I hated the game but as time went by and I got more experience, it felt better and better to play. The learning process of bosses, mechanics and all that wasn't as fun but man it felt good in the end. The game gets more fun as you get more and more upgrades so don't give up on it too early on. Most boss designs are simple but nice. And the most exciting part about the game I would say it's the world building and story. This is the perfect example of show don't tell. I love when developers do that, I don't have to read a million lines before I can play again, just enough talking to learn information and then the rest is shown through the map game cutscenes etc. I love how pretty much everything ties to the lore it makes everything so interesting. One of the best worlds/lore I've experienced in a game. For anyone thinking about playing the game, what you should know is that the game is pretty hard at times (especially on the first run) and kinda merciless at times but even with that in mind you should give it a try and see for yourself if you like it.

I want to like it, but I just can't so many deaths feel cheap and out of place it's insane, it makes me rage quit every time. In most metroidvanias you feel powerful while remaining vulnerable and this game you just lose for the sake of losing. 

For how difficult the bosses are (<- that's good) benches are extremely far away (<-that's bad) you lose half your HP before you even reach them. And you can't even practice them in anyway before that. Half of the journey is travelling to the boss rooms.

The nail arts are so inapplicable in an actual combat scenario it's basically just there for show. You can hit them once per hard fight if your pre-prep it before you get there and that's.. that's it...

Backtracking is INSANE, and the fast travel is *extremely* limited. It is also extremely unclear where you should go in this game, one wrong step and poof enemies just delete you or you're in a boss room without even knowing. It reminds me of the SNES times where you needed a booklet with a guide to backseat you the entire game.

If you play aimlessly, like I did you backtrack and retrace steps way more than you actually play the game, it gets boring.

Playing with with a guide to backseat you also gets boring, but there is no other way to play.

This is an excellent metroidvania. The world and its lore is rather opaque initially, and there is a "well, what do I do now?" situation twice in the game as you're exploring, but you eventually find what you need to do if you explore diligently. The main gripe I have with the game is the fast travel locations are not well placed and a number of important shops require tedious re-traversal to return to. In addition, the decision to not make the map for a particularly centrally located area attainable until extremely late in the game is quite a bizarre one. However, despite its flaws, the game is thoroughly enjoyable and is one of the best in the genre.

Hollow Knight Review

Hollow Knight is honestly a fantastic game, though at first, I wasn't that impressed. In the beginning, the gameplay feels pretty basic and you don't have a lot of skills or flashy abilities. The early upgrades you find aren't too challenging to get, so it can seem a bit simple at the start.

But once I got deeper into the game and started encountering the bosses, everything changed. The bosses are one of the best parts of the experience‚Äîthey‚Äôre interesting, memorable, and really elevate the exploration. I also realized I was playing with the DLC already included, which added even more depth. It took me over 30 hours to beat, and I enjoyed nearly every minute.

I do wish the game had a few more ways to experiment with different weapons‚Äîlike maybe a big axe or some kind of ranged weapons, bows, or arrows‚Äîjust to add a little variety. And maybe having more bosses per area would be nice for even more of those epic fights.

Overall, though, it's a fantastic indie game from a small studio, and I‚Äôd easily give it a 9 out of 10‚Äîmaybe even a 9.5. It's memorable, it's great for what it is, and I absolutely recommend it.

The TLDR of Hollow Knight is simple: It's an extremely high quality Metroidvania that is well worth the price.

It reminds me of an old school Blizzard game in the way that it doesn't do a lot that's really new or boundary pushing, but instead takes a grab bag of familiar and popular elements and combines them in a satisfying way all while polishing them to a mirror sheen.

This game is a 2D action game with light RPG elements and medium platforming elements.  The game is one big interconnected map where exploration is gated behind abilities found after either boss battles or exploration.  The light RPG elements are most similar to Zelda: A Link to the Past - extra health and mp nodes, new spells, and new weapon techniques.  The RPG elements may go a touch further with charms that can enhance basic stats like damage to a degree.  This enables a basic "build" customization system, albeit one that is simpler than many other metroidvanias and 2D souls likes. 

Two elements of the game stick out as the best it offers: The combat and the Music.  
     The combat features some extremely precise controls which allows for precision maneuvers.  The arc of your jump is controlled by how long you press the jump button and the same precision is applied to your horizontal movement as well.  Bosses have contact damage and fair hitboxes, therefore fighting them often requires the precision offered by the controls.  I found the combat challenging but not unfair for the most part.  Admittedly, I didn't bother with the vast majority of extra combat challenges, only a few of the extra dreaming bosses added in by the DLC.  I fought Grimm a few times but never beat him.  I unlocked the more powerful dream nail but didn't complete the white palace.  I only unlocked the most basic ending.  When the time came to start finishing those big end-game challenges, there were two matters of personal taste which turned me to the direction of choosing to move onto another title on my very crowded.  I'll discuss those when I talk about the weaker parts of the game.
     The music of this game is excellent, and it combines with an overall great sound design that actually has a noticeable effect on the gameplay.  Musical cues are often present to provide the player a cue to what's happening, and even when the music isn't working towards that, the tracks are all extremely high quality.  The only aspect of the sound-design which I don't care for is the deafening of the sound when struck in combat.  In a similar fashion to the much maligned "red vision" (although not nearly as bad), I find the hollow knight "black vision" after taking damage to be a tad too distracting.

Now we'll deal with what are, in my subjective opinion, the weaker aspects of the game:  The story and the art design.  
     I'll get the art design out of the way first.  I first want to recognize that I don't in anyway believe it's half-assed or poorly conceived.  It was very intentionally designed, it's consistent, and its themes show through in basically every area.  The problem is that it's just not for me.  It's a simplistic bug theme that fell through a Tim Burton filter and then landed in a Dark Souls "decayed kingdom" pit.  That was just never going to resonate that strongly with me, but I can admire how much work (especially given the team-size) went into making the most of they have.
     I wish I could bring that same level of grudging praise to the story, but alas, I don't find the "story" near as defensible.  The story is a poor Dark Souls rip-off that is transposed onto a bug kingdom instead of a traditional sword and sorcery setting.  The NPCs who are part of the "plot" speak in basic riddles, but most of the NPCs don't know wtf is going on with the plot because the plot is practically non-existent.  You're a non-talking amnesiac in another fallen/ruined kingdom that suffering from a spat of corruption.  It's the same damn plot as every Dark Souls game and every wanna be Dark Souls game.  It's another "lorey" a "story" that is told almost exclusively through Lore about the past, rather events in the present.  Also, I'm very tired of try-hard "tragic" NPC stories where you save a bunch of NPCs only for them to die in the end.  That elicits little more than a shrug of my shoulders.

So the story not being compelling was a big reason that I didn't bother with the extra-end game challenges, however the second major factor is my general dislike of difficult platforming.  This is in no way a knock against the platforming of Hollow Knight.  As far as I can tell, Hollow Knight's platforming is high quality as those things go.  I just consider difficult Indie platformers as a niche that is not mine.  I tried Super-Meat Boy and didn't care for it.  I never bothered with Celeste or any other highly regarded Indie Platformer.  It's just not a genre I care about.  None of the platforming in this game gave me serious pause until I got to the white palace, which is one big platforming challenge.  The other endings are gated behind this challenge, and because I don't care about the story, I didn't bother trying to achieve those additional endings.

Overall, I greatly enjoyed my time with the game.  If you like 2D Dark Souls type games, traditional 2D action games, or Metroidvanias, this game is probably for you and certainly worth its price.

I really wanted to like this game, but this is probably the most overglazed and overhyped game of all time. It is regularly called the "Souls-like Metroidvania," but a better comparison would be to call it the Fortnite of Metroidvanias becuase it's not really that deep, but appeals to mainstream gamers who aren't really that deep into the Metroidvania genre, or gaming as a whole. And don't get me wrong, this game is fun at times, but it excels at nothing and is rather bland as a whole. If you are looking for a visually striking, creative and innovative Metroidvania with challenging or even souls-like combat, play Blasphemous or Symphony of the Night instead. This game is not that, contrary to what others say.

As a Metroidvania, it is probably the most shallow and uninteresting Metroidvania I have ever played. The level design is extremely repetitive and bland, The exploration appears open yet lacks any vision and ends up being largely linear and involves you often walking in circles until you find a hidden door you missed. There is very little movement growth, really only getting a dash, wall jump and double jump. Back tracking is not rewarding because by the time you get anything out of it you've already run through the same area 10 times already. The environments also lack visual clarity and often look more or less the same screen from screen. While some Metroidvania's make more use of the map than others, A large portion of this game's upgrades are just adding rudimentary features to the map like showing your cursor on the map or marking merchants on it. This really isn't much of a Metroidvania as much as it is a walking simulator because the movement is so slow and you spend so much time trudging through the same areas over and over.

As a Souls-like, the Combat is extremely shallow and a complete letdown. Combat in it's entirety really just boils down to just mashing a single button and has virtually zero depth. Parry timing is extremely tight and while it does nullify a single instance of damage, it's ultimately better just to button mash and deal damage than it is to strategically bait out a parry. Dodging provides zero Iframes and is purely a traversal tool here, further limiting combat to this passive game of chicken where you run in, mash, run away, repeat. Even among Metroidvanias, which to be frank, usually have lackluster Combat: Hollow Knight stands out as exceptionally repetitive and bland in virtually every aspect. The only reason this game gets called a souls-like is because it has corpse running (IE: Death = you must recover your body or all your currency is lost) and because it has a parry button. Controls are sluggish and the opposite of tight. Frankly, calling it a Souls-like is an insult to Soulslikes.

The Art style and Lore seems to carry this game in the eyes of many, but to be honest, that is also rather basic and shallow. Character sprites are minimalistic, bland and even when they are distinct from one another, there isn't much interest to them. The NPC's also have virtually zero dimension to them, so there's not really any reason to be invested in them or their (non-existent) stories. Assets and Backgrounds don't really match in terms of style or level of detail. Characters have thick, blocky lines and no shading or detail whatsoever, while backgrounds are highly detailed, shaded and static.

If I didn't get this game for under $5, I would probably really disappointed. It's not a terrible game, but there are flash games of equal or superior quality from like 2008 both graphically and mechanically.

I'm a casual game and this is probably one of the hardest games I've played in my entire life and yet I understand why people love it. Hollow Knight filled me with frustration, rage, and pain, and yet, the moment I beat a boss (*cough* Hornet *cough*), I can't describe the joy I felt üò≠
If you're looking a challenge, amazing music and unique graphics/art, look no further.

I've got to say, this game is my favorite. Now I've said that about plenty of games before, but I genuinely think that this game is my favorite. It's held my attention longer than most other games have, and it's able to make this fun whilst still being challenging. Oh, and the storytelling? I've rarely seen this kind of storytelling, where you are given nothing but hints and clues as to what is happening. Most games I've played will give a background on the main objective or the overall story, or the story will be made apparent to me about half-way through the game. However, this game has its story hidden in the world around you, and you'll have to pay attention to grasp some semblance of understanding as to what is happening. This game was the first time I actually had to take notes. Like, pause the game, think about what happened, and write about it in my notes app. And I've still got no clue as to what's happening! Which, for some reason, makes me even more interested. Though it isn't perfect, and at times frustrating, I still think its one of the best games I've ever played.

I LOVE HOLLOW KNIGHT

This was surely a trip, and a very pleasant and enjoyable one.

A Metroidvania with a lot of collectibles, many and hidden areas to discover and explore, to get stronger, and to progress more and more. I was surprised at what things one comes across when just wanting to explore an area, giving some pleasant surprises which I've liked a lot.

The difficulty felt very fair to me, most bosses being done first try, but there were quite the exceptions among them which forces the player to go into serious mode. Some challenges which require some good skills, a good balance between comfortable gameplay and required focus to overcome the harsher tasks.

I delayed to finish the game simply because it was fun to still look for what I couldn't solve until that time, only looking up one thing, and two to confirm my thoughts. Beating it to 100%, one can say I've found 99% of everything myself, and it felt good and rewarding.

The soundtrack fits very well into the entire game's atmosphere, gloomy and sometimes beyond, making it a pleasant game for the ears as well. 

There's only one and odd complain I have about the game.
The complain about that there's nothing I really can complain about. And that is good.
Replay value is also given for the people who enjoy the trip and want to stay long with the game which is absolutely a good move.

Love the game, and can easily recommend it if you like to explore areas, get rewarded for your efforts, enjoy a moderate difficulty, and go into serious mode when attempting the harsher challenges.

Like many others say, the game is good enough until you realize how unforgiving the checkpoint system is. Most reviews I see talk about this. You reach the first really tough boss, end up losing over and over again and are reset to a checkpoint that is miles away to walk all the way back and try again.

This is a souls like game that instead of offering you retries, punishes you for dying. Oh you lost? Now walk all the way back from beginning. Also you lose all your upgrades until you reach the point where you last lost. Then HOPE you don't die again to waste more time traveling back to the fight AGAIN.

IT's a cute game, good music, good graphics, fun game play. AWFULLY unforgiving checkpoint system with no retry option for tough battles. Quality of life is VERY low on this game. I may not play again for a long time if ever. I've wasted my money.
Best game ever, have 112% completion

I've never played a metroidvania game before. I thought I wouldn't like it, but I love it.

The art design is beautiful. The characters, the animations, the scenery, the soundtrack, the ambience, and the voice acting are just perfect for the playful, but melancholic atmosphere of Hollow Nest, which I would argue is a little gem of world-building by itself. It's what carries the game most.

As for the game-play, its very snappy and satisfying, clever at times. Given its difficulty reputation I feared it would frustrate me. Surprisingly, despite some off-putting moments, it didn't. Yes, there are parts of the game where dying can be a bit too punishing (i.e. large distances or lengthy sequences after the last checkpoint), some where the difficulty spikes way above average to almost ridiculous degrees (e.g. [spoiler]the last stage of The Coliseum of Fools[/spoiler] or [spoiler]the saw section of The White Palace[/spoiler]), and some where it seems a bit of a filler (e.g. traveling way too many times to the same, unluckily distant, already visited places). Still, I wanted to discover the world and its story so much that it didn't bother me. On the contrary, I thought the harshness of it fit the setting.

I have a habit of playing games that require good timing and coordination, so don't be fooled: it is quite challenging if you're a casual player. But don't let that discourage you. :-)

My only gripe with the game is that there are a few points where it's almost impossible to figure out how to progress without taking a look at a guide or spending enormous amounts of time retracing steps and guessing possibilities because it's hinted nowhere near well enough. I did the former, but I guess the latter is part of the appeal for some.

I bought it for 7.40‚Ç¨ (50% off), but it does deserve the full price.

Late to playing this game, since I initially overlooked it due to it not being my typical style of game. I got caught up in the Silksong hype and decided to finally give it a try first.

Just about finished with the main story (going for the True ending) and have to say, I understand the hype. I'd easily add it to my top 5 games list, and love so much about it, from the gameplay and controls, to the atmosphere, story, and enemies. I'll admit, it's difficult (and rewarding) and I'm definitely not very good at this style of game, but through all the deaths at boss battles, I can't stop coming back. I don't think I'll be the person who does all the rematches or toughest battles in the game (who knows, many have likely said that), but I've enjoyed nearly every boss and challenge, always wanting to come back to finish it, no matter how many times I've died (similar to how I feel about Cuphead). 

My only caveat, is it is not one of those games that gets easier as you go, even with new abilities. It stays difficult, which I think is good, but not for everyone. If someone comes into this expecting an easy adventure, this is not the right game for them. Just good for people to be aware of that, but if someone wants to take the time to learn and explore what Hollow Knight has to offer, and has the patience to struggle through it, it is so worth it.

[h1] My favorite game of all time [/h1]
For reference, I have around 30 hours on steam for this game, but had originally gotten up to 280 hours on my switch back in March when I saw it on E-shop

TLDR; fuck you read the damn review

Hollow Knight is a metroidvania. About bugs. I hate bugs irl, which makes it ironic for how much I adore this game. Everything is perfect. The combat is fluid and swift once you master it, the platforming is satisfying and rewarding to learn, exploration is direly important, and in mix with both combat and platforming, is consistently rewarding to collect one of the 44 charms, 3 spells and 3 upgrades, 3 nail arts, 6 materials for the nail upgrades, multiple skills to discover more, and countless items, currency, and rewards.

The fallen kingdom of Hallownest is both charming and enigmatic, and is a wonder to explore. The kingdom and its inhabitants, from the somber Dirtmouth, to the beautiful capital, to the harrowing Deepnest, each area is able to get you immersed into it, and asking yourself about its history prior to your  entrance. Every area has many secrets that will require players to use the platforming, combat, or just their curiosity to discover and learn about its lore.

Each npc, vendor, and massive variety of enemies are all masterfully crafted. Even the smallest bits of dialogue from the most unimportant character will reveal a new piece of the puzzle to solve the mystery of what happened to this kingdom. Vendors, even when uncharismatic, will still grab your attention and will make you want to learn more about their backstory, or at the very least, what they have to offer. Enemies will range from cute little guys to intimidating beast, the masterclass warriors.

All 44 bosses (besides like 2 of them) are engaging and majestic, each one requiring you to learn and adapt to their movesets to survive the encounters you'll have with them, ranging from passionate rituals, to savage brawls, to skillful duels, and emotional clashes to decide the kingdoms fate. No boss truly dissapoints.

Of course, none of these aspects could shine as brightly as they do without being accompanied with Christopher Larkins's divine soundtrack. No area, enemy, character, or scene is accompanied with an unfitting theme, all soundtracks are able to elevate each moment to the grand stage of your mind.

Spent like 20 minutes writing this review, so you know its worth it. More effort than I put into most of my assignments.

This game is a lot of fun, with the music, atmosphere and and art style being the big standouts for me. Combat is great too, for the most part, and the story and lore is interesting, if deliberately opaque and inaccessible. My biggest problem with Hollow Knight is that some parts of the game seem designed to be annoying and to waste your time. I'm mostly talking about boss run backs. Just for example, putting 3 platforms in the corridor leading to Hornet in Kingdom's Edge to stop you from getting to her in one crystal dash is just obnoxious. Some bosses have a lot of enemies you have to fight to get back to them every time, but I don't mind that as much as the ones that just take a lot of time to get to, because Team Cherry wanted to do some atmospheric story telling on your first go, and decided that shortcuts for subsequent fights weren't something that they wanted to do (looking at you Nosk.).

I think that deliberate opaqueness is a part of what makes progressing through the game feel interesting and engaging, but it can also create needless frustration. Never communicating certain movement options to the player can make some parkour sections really hard, and make you feel like an idiot when you do figure it out. 

Also, the lack of player character choice regarding interactions with certain NPCs baffles me, as do some of the arbitrary restrictions placed on who you can and cannot kill. Team Cherry has a very deliberate experience they want to create, and sometimes that can take you out of the game when you can't do X thing now because they want you to experience Y later. This can be pretty jarring sometimes.

Despite all of the above, I really like Hollow Knight. It's probably one of the best games that I've ever played. Most of the things that annoy me about it seem to be deliberate choices on the part of the developer, which I respect even if I don't like. Buying a game like this for 8 euro is very very reasonable. So far only Skyrim LE for 16 euro all those years ago has been better value for money. Some people say that a playthrough will take 20-30 hours, but given that I'm 53 hours in and think I still have another 10 at least to go before I reach an ending, I'd take this with a grain of salt.

GOOD GOD THIS GAME IS AMAZING. I have played it pretty much everyday for the past 2 weeks, it's all I can think about when I'm away from home, it's insane. The gameplay is so smooth and easy to pick up on, and the combat is fluid and fun. There's so much to explore, even when you think you've filled out your map completely you'll end up breaking a wall here or crashing through a floor there, and bam-whole new area! You can tell the devs put a lot of heart and soul into this game, there's so much content it's almost overwhelming.

The soundtrack is probably the best part in my opinion (already bought that too). It's a gorgeous, melancholy score that perfectly accompanies the different areas you travel to throughout the game. 

I have yet to beat the game yet despite almost 40 hours of gameplay, but I can say with confidence that this is one of my favorite games I've ever played. Even if you might not like metroidvanias, give it a try!

This is a great game - you should absolutely play it if you like or are interested in the platformer or metroidvania genres, unless you have poor reflexes and are impatient. It's not a game you can brute force your way through. It punishes the unskilled with save spots being far apart, so there's a lot of back tracking and in the case of boss battles it can be really frustrating to die, travel back, then die again. Fast travel spots are also too far apart, so a lot of exploration involves back tracking. Whats really annoying and disrespectful development is that mid-late game you get the ability to set return points.

Hollow Knight surprised me with how well everything fits together. The story doesn‚Äôt hold your hand - you uncover it piece by piece - and that makes every discovery feel earned. The characters, even with minimal dialogue, manage to be memorable and strangely emotional.

The soundtrack is incredible. Every area has music that perfectly matches its atmosphere, from calm and mysterious to tense and haunting. It really pulls you into Hallownest.

Gameplay is where the game shines the most: tight controls, challenging but fair combat, and exploration that constantly rewards curiosity. When you fail, it‚Äôs on you. When you win, it feels great.

Overall, it‚Äôs one of the most polished and atmospheric games I‚Äôve played. If you like metroidvanias or just want an immersive world to get lost in, this is absolutely worth your time.

At first I didn't know what I was getting into. At the end I came out a changed person. This is one of the BIGGEST, most intricately designed, best controlling, most challenging, most beautiful looking and sounding, beathtaking exploration action games I have ever played (and I play a lot of those). This is not for the faint of heart, it requires your attention, your concentration and every ounce of your skills, as the combat was forged in the fires of Souls-like games, but once it clicks you'll be clashing blades throwing spells and pogo-ing off enemies heads in a breeze. I love how the game trusts that you can go and get lost or find your way, and that it doesn't really hold your hand, a trait that's becoming rarer and rarer among games these days. Go ahead and play it.

Just make sure you have a controller with a good D-pad.

Just 100% this again after not playing it for years. Still holds up, even after silksong and remains one of my all time favorites. Definitely give it a chance if you never have. Time to go for 112% and rage all over again.

(NO SPOILERS)
Summary:
Forge your own path in Hollow Knight! An epic action adventure through a vast ruined kingdom of insects and heroes. Explore twisting caverns, battle tainted creatures and befriend bizarre bugs, all in a classic, hand-drawn 2D style.
-------------------------------
What is in the game:
Hollow Knight is a huge Metroidvania where you explore the vast kingdom of Hollownest and discover its history. It has a giant main quest with a ton of side quests and side content you can find with a lot of different bosses and enemy types.
-------------------------------
Thoughts:
I regret putting this game off for so long. This is the best Metroidvania I have played so far in trying out the genre. It has amazing gameplay that feels fun and challenging, amazing visuals, great music, a huge amount of content, and a really cool and interesting world and story. While there aren't many recurring characters in the story, the few there are are all likable and all feel unique. I really like the way it tells the story, where most of the time it leaves it up to your interpretation and doesn't tell you stuff directly. The game is just really goddamn fun; I couldn't put it down. While I didn't get ALL of the content because I just didn't really want to do the stuff that was left, I put off finishing the game to get to 108% completion with all the side content before doing the final boss, and I highly recommend doing side content if you play this game too. I also likes how doing the side content all mostly felt natural, I barely had to search up how to find anything, and what I did was just me forgetting some stuff from the beginning of the game. Overall, please try this game at some point; the overwhelmingly positive reviews are there for a reason.
-------------------------------
Mid PC Optimization:
This ran at 400 fps constantly; you shouldn't have any fps issues with this game.
-------------------------------
Time to Beat:
~20 hours for just doing the main content, and probably ~40+ for 100% of the content (actually 112%).
-------------------------------
Price:
‚òë Buy it full
‚òê Wait for sale
‚òê Don't buy it
‚òê Free
For the huge amount of content, amazing quality, and indie team, I 100% think you should buy Hollow Knight full price.
-------------------------------
Graphics:
‚òë Amazing
‚òê Good
‚òê Average
‚òê Bad
‚òê Awful
The art is simply amazing; all the animations look great, and the environments all feel unique and are beautiful. And very importantly, I feel like this game never has environments that make the enemies kind of blend in; you will never miss enemies because they blend in. I feel like I can't really do the art justice; just look at the store page screenshots.
-------------------------------
Gameplay:
‚òë Very Fun
‚òê Fun
‚òê Meh
‚òê Bad
‚òê Awful
The gameplay just gets more fun as it goes on; it's a rewarding challenge. At first, I'll be honest, it starts a little slow, but after maybe 2 hours, it starts clicking more as you get more and more abilities. Exploring the world is great, and all the enemies feel unique. Side content is all fun, and you actually feel like it's worth doing, unlike a lot of games. I also feel like this game is just really clear with where you need to go; I rarely got lost, and when I did, it was just because I'm stupid. I also like how the side content added in updates doesn't feel too tacked on; it feels like it was always there for the most part. Overall, it's just a really fun Metroidvania that makes you just want to keep going and keep exploring.

All around, I'd consider this in my top 3 games of all time. The world-building, music score, ambiance, crisp/responsive gameplay, sense of exploration; it's the full package. It is challenging and at times a bit tedious, but honestly I was so immersed in the world that I did not care. I would say don't feel scared to pull up the wiki or an interactive map if you get lost, because you may get stumped on occasion, but the world is so jam-packed that you'll find something else quickly to try to explore.
awesome.

I first picked up Hollow Knight in 2018 on the Switch. In the years since, I replayed it 4-5 times, always enjoying the return to Hollownest. Once this game opens up, there's so much to explore, background lore to discover, and fine tuned game mechanics to master and fall in love with. It was hard, but fair.

After the release of Silksong and the step up in challenge it provided, I decided to get the game again for PC and see what it was like to return once again. The result is that I discovered how much better I had gotten at it than I realized. I could actually do Steel Soul quite easily, get the speedrun achievements, and finally try the pantheons. After a week, I have 100% a game I was certain I never would.

Ultimately, I can't recommend games by Team Cherry enough. I think they have a knack for using their gameplay to teach you all you need to know. As someone who had over 30+ attempts on certain bosses the first time he played this game can attest, it's possible and you don't have to be lucky. The reward is usually just more challenge, and I'm here for it.

However, with that being said i think this game does have certain small balancing issues that make no sense to me. Like, for example, my last experience with this game was suffering with the mantis traitor boss. I personally feel that hollow knight is an amazing games, however experiences like that are simply why it isn't a 10/10 personally, as much as it hurts to give it a 8/10.

This game is so much fun, but it seems like it desperately doesn't want you to find that out.

I tried to play this game numerous times after it looked so fun in clips I saw of various bosses, but the start was just so confusing and boring that I struggled every time. I felt like I was looping through samey corridors with no idea where I was supposed to be going. I believe this was my fourth time trying to start Hollow Knight, and I told myself that I would just stick with it until I hit that good point, and it finally came.

Once you get past the rough start, this game is extraordinary. Simple but challenging combat, loads of satisfying movement options that you unlock throughout the game, a really cute art style, and tons of secrets to find across the world. I found myself really really enjoying the game once I got into the swing of things.

However, this game does have two painful downsides that I had to mod the game to overcome, otherwise the game just felt like it was artificially stretching out its runtime - the checkpoint and fast travel systems. 

Whenever you would die, you'd respawn at a bench and you'd have to collect your soul to regain all your money. This is fine. However, the benches can sometimes be quite far from boss rooms. There are some bosses that are a three or four minute journey away from the nearest bench, meaning every time you die there's effectively a four minute loading screen after each attempt. This isn't engaging or anything, this is just painful. There is a mod that respawns you in the room you died, which fixed this issue for me by allowing me to jump straight back into boss fights.

The other issue, the fast travel system, is purely because there are so few fast travel points. The world in this game is huge, and each area has a fast travel point. If you've got an area you want to check out for one quick thing, that can sometimes take you upwards of 20 minutes to get there and back to where you came from. This game is full of backtracking and using your new abilities to find secrets in existing areas, so the lack of a variety of fast travel points really hurts this game. The bench warp mod fixed this for me and allowed me to get into the meat of the game much more consistently.

So while this game is a ton of fun when you're actually exploring or engaging in combat, the rough start and sluggish unmodded pacing definitely hurts the game a lot. Fixing the majority of those issues with mods, this game becomes an absolute joy to play.
It's truly a fun game, the combat was not what I'm used to but quickly became a favourite of mine, and the story is really intriguing. It is a great exploratory adventure that's satisfying to play.

Hollow Knight is a versatile and expansive experience that any avid gamer should have in their indie game utility belt, and fits a bunch of different preferences

In terms of the art style, the character design can be often adorable, whilst the environment sets a dark and gothic theme. The sound design, too, is impeccable, from the oddly satisfying shrieks of various bugs to the wonderfully cinematic soundtrack behind everything.

When it comes to story, it may not be the most obvious at first what's going on, but one of the joys in playing this game is uncovering the past of both the empty protagonist and the dead kingdom in which you explore. There are also many secrets to discover, often providing further story insight, or even entire subsections of the game. Every single friend and foe, location, and all in between comes with extensive lore built in.

Gameplay, while at times becoming frustrating in parkour and combat challenges, ultimately increases the psychological reward in being able to complete. Fair warning: each boss will take generally between a single try to up to ten or twenty attempts to defeat, so you'll have enough room to take in the importance of both being attentive to enemy move-sets and strategizing your own moves. Speaking of which, you will have ample upgrades to acquire throughout as essential parts of the progression. A perfect mix between the Metroidvania and Souls-like genres, if you ask me. All of the enemies have their quirks and each boss is entirely memorable in their glory or lack thereof. 

Also, when I say expansive, you can go from putting small scavenging bugs in their place in the start of the game to infiltrating dreams, completing a dark ritual for a sinister circus, and even slaying gods!

All within the cheap package of Hollow Knight, for your gaming needs.

...Oh, and good luck with the Primal Aspids...

This game is my currently my fav games of all time. But do i think its perfect? FUCK NO. Do i suggest it to people who love metroidvania games or to people who want to get into the genre? Definitely! This game has charm and beauty seeping through the seams. There also a SHIT tun of things to do that are completely  optional and aren't necessary in the slight way possible. For example [spoiler] doing all the bindings in the pantheons (boss rushes) [/spoiler]. I've spent 72 hours on steam alone and roughly another 70 hours on my xbox. This games has so much to it and i love it. its an almost perfect games but some of the areas when exploring are terrible. there either have really shit platforming design or really shit enemy design. For example [spoiler] queens garden [/spoiler] is a really annoying area to traverse through due to its annoying platforming that you have to go through and the annoying enemies that slow you down. it isn't too annoying of an area but its enough to make feel like im suffering. the same goes for [spoiler]the hive[/spoiler] . the only difference being that [spoiler] queens garden[/spoiler]  is visually stunning. speaking of visually stunning almost all areas are beautiful. the only ones that aren't are the ones that are designed to look gloomy or creepy (except from [spoiler] the hive[/spoiler]. that area is an actual ball ache to look at for me) . the areas use these beautiful colours that will give you an eyegasm. another thing that will make you eyes cum is the art style and the character designs its so good. everything is hand drawn to perfection and nothing ever feels out of place. and the character designs are a whole thing its self. every enemy is designed around the area its in and all of them fit together to make either beautiful or gloomy that fits the mood too well. and the lore of the game is whole different rabbit whole that i wont be going down and one i don't understand but you don't need to fully understand it all. you can try and piece it together yourself or watch a guide. personally i got some of the law from friends who had been playing before me and somehow ive made more progress than them and they've had the game longer than i have by literal months or years. thats how much i love this game. there are a total of 5 endings. which two are basically the same ending but changes slight visually and another two endings that are basically the same but the cut scene is a little longer basically showing off something. (may be lore related. i haven't got a fucking clue). another thing to talk about are the bosses. most of them are amazing. they either teach the player through the beginning of the game, give some challenge to the player but are still enjoyable or are so hard it makes you want to rip your teeth out. i love the majority of the bosses. most of them aren't that bad except for a few that are just more tedious rather than hard but the bosses are still one of the best things about the game. another one of the best things about the game is the soundtrack. its amazing. it fits the game so well and most of the songs you could easily fall asleep to and a few are actual bangers. 

anyways i think ive yapped for long enough now. to whoever reads this (which will probably be no one) play this game. its so good

Hollow Knight completely blew me away. The world is beautiful and atmospheric, the controls feel super smooth, and exploring Hallownest never gets old. Every area feels handcrafted, and the more you explore, the more the world opens up in the most rewarding ways. Every boss fight feels tough but fair, and beating them is insanely satisfying‚Äîyou really feel yourself improving as you go. The music is gorgeous, the art is stunning, and there‚Äôs just so much to do that I kept finding new things even dozens of hours in. I honestly didn‚Äôt expect a game this polished and memorable for the price. I loved every minute of it. I recommend it to everyone.

Honestly I don't get why this game is overwhelmingly positive. Is it good? yes, but overwhelmingly? IMO no.

Half if not most of the game is running around trying to figure out what you're supposed to do, I don't find that fun. I would have preferred to have directions or a hint on where to go or something.
Yes exploring is fun, but not when you spend most of your time going over the areas you've already been, running around trying to find what the next objective is. Imagine GTA V but without mission markers. It gets boring and annoying having to google everything.

Later on you can buy markers to put on your map. Great! just mark where I've already been or where I want to come back, right? NOPE, you get a max of 6 markers (for each color) for whatever reason.

Ok I'll just remember where I've been, right? Well, what happens when I don't play for a few weeks then come back? already forgot everything.

Then during boss fights, or I guess in general, if you die, instead of respawning nearby, you respawn at the last bench you saved at. It's not fun and frustrating dying and then having to walk all the way back while taking damage along the way.

Then there's also the fact that, for whatever fucking reason, in order to see where you are on the map you need to sacrifice a slot which could be used for other upgrades. Same thing for automatically picking up dropped coins from monsters, like why aren't they just permanent upgrades?

I'll probably still finish the game, but I wanted to share my frustrating experience for a supposedly top rated game.

Genuinely, as a person who generally dislikes these types of games; i.e 'extreme difficulty', time commitment, etc, I think Hollow Knight has balanced these negative aspects very well. Between the fun bosses as well as exploration, I can say that out of the thirty hours I have sunk here, I have enjoyed a significant majority of them. That is not to say it is all sunshine and rainbows, as there are many sections that I found very annoying, especially runbacks on bosses. This is especially true for a few bosses such as WK and the bee guy. Furthermore, there is a complete change that occurs after a certain checkpoint that makes traversing one area extremely annoying. Other than that, I think that you should definitely experience this game. The first hour is annoying, but from then on, fun awaits.

Playing this game late at night with an arcade stick and using Astien's VR Enhanced Mod is a transcendent experience that you owe it to yourself to experience at least once!

I honestly did not expect to like this game nearly as much as I have been, I wish I could say good graphics and charm was enough to keep me playing a side-scroller... But, it isn't. My library is full of amazing indie games I can't bring myself to ever boot up or finish.. Hollow Knight on the other hand is something special to be able to hook me and keep my ADHD brain engaged and constantly wanting more the entire time.
 
The art is breathtaking especially when experienced in 3D using the VR Enhanced Mod, the sound design is great! Not just the music but all the little sound effects and characters as well. The world is massive, the powers and abilities are plentiful, the enemies are both engaging and varied. Oh.. and the price is reasonable?

I didn't think I liked Metroidvanias. Actually, I think I still don't like them.. I think I just fell in love with Hollow Knight. Can't wait to continue exploring knowing that the sequel Silksong will be just as great when I'm finished!

I played this game four other times and never got to fare into it and I all was shat on Hollow Knight as a game, now this game did not chance my life or anything special I still think is a mid game at best for me there are a lot of pros but I felt a lot of cons wile playing. Pros of Hollow Knight I loved the early/mid game and how mysterious the game feels to some one who has never played the game before and the nail combat plus the movement felt real nice to play with, and the challenge of the game did not feel bad at all to me I sure felt it with some bosses and areas but it never felt impossible. Cons of Hollow Knight I want to start this part if the review by saying I did beat the game and got skill but that aside I still feel like I want to point the cons of the game that I have with it. Con one for me will be the art style of the game I am not calling the art bad it just did not pop to me, con two the late game in a whole I did not like the late game of Hollow Knight and for me the late game of Hollow Knight to be after you have done all dreamers and for me I also explored the whole map and picked a fight with every boss I found but I still did not feel good fighting some of these bosses such as White-Defender, Lost Kin, and all dream bosses as a whole accept for Nightmare King Grimm witch to me is the best boss in the whole game and the best boss that team charry has ever made. (not I never beat all Pantheons I got to P3 and then felt satisfied enough with myself to move on to Silksong)   

 At the end of the day this game gave me a strong 4/10 I liked a lot of good aspects of the game but I feel to me the the cons I have outweigh the pros in my eyes.

Idk how to really feel about Hollow Knight. Like the world, characters, music is just 10/10 but like the combat feels so clunky idk and the lack of options in it (nail+spells and that's it). I wish there was more options how to approach the fights, either with different weapons or mechanics other than pogo-ing (there is a "parry" system but the game doesnt tell you about it so you will not even know it until you see a vid on YouTube explaining it) this brings me to the biggest flaw of the whole game and that is Team Cherry doing weird and annoying gameplay choices. Infected crossroads being the biggest one. Why block parts of the map for no reason? Then theres a bit of a personal flaw i have and that is benchwarping. The amount of backtracking you have to do in this game is insane which isnt the problem, it is a metroidvania but having a good fast travel system should be in every single one. And Hollow Knight does it the worst. With the stag stations. I wish we got a ability to warp to the benches we rest at as in other metroidvanias like blasphemous. Also the main bosses are really fun but when you do the dlc bosses they are for some reason completely cracked on coke and you have almost no chance of reacting (unless you are a psychopath that has 10k hours in it). Fuck you Nightmare King Grim! Anyways its a great game but i recommend playing with mods like benchwarp.

I bought this game due to its souls-like tag and the high praise it receives. While the former isn‚Äôt justified, the latter absolutely is. 

I‚Äôm not really into platformers, but this game was a wonderful, challenging adventure. The care that was put into every detail is clear: be it the score, character designs, animations, or literally any other aspect. 

Despite this not being the type of game I prefer to play, I‚Äôm certain that I‚Äôll come back to it sometime, and I‚Äôll have another incredible experience.

I've beat the game, mostly, and in line with my typical way of writing reviews of games I like, I will only mention the issues I have with it, because to mention everything good would just be repeating what everyone else has positive to say.

I hate contact damage, the combat is built around melee attacks, so it just doesn't work with contact damage, I think it would be much better if the enemies did a block and if you walked through them then you'd take damage, I think that would make the nail arts actually usable.

Overall 9/10, if you like metroidvanias, or even games in general BUY THIS GAME.

This isn‚Äôt just another game - it‚Äôs an entire world you never want to leave. Every pixel, every corner of the map (each with its own unforgettable design), every character (and don‚Äôt even get me started on the bosses - some fights feel like a perfectly choreographed dance) - it‚Äôs all something beyond real.

With every new playthrough, you start noticing little details you missed before. The amount of content is insane. Animations, gameplay, audio - everything blends together so seamlessly that it all feels natural, almost alive. You forget it‚Äôs even a game.

Sure, it‚Äôs not the easiest experience, especially for newcomers. But the idea is simple: if you keep dying in a certain area a hundred thousand times (and still are), chances are you‚Äôve wandered in too early and need to level up - both your skills and your character. The key is not to rush - take your time, explore, and dig into every nook and cranny you can find.

And the awesome DLCs? They‚Äôll give you countless unforgettable hours of pure joy *git gud*

I write as a busy person that just completed the main storyline after 30h. Hollow Knight was one of the most enjoyable and compelling single player experiences in a while. I usually avoid challenging single player games. Call them "souls-like" if you want. But Hollow Knight feels like a gate-way drug into the genre. Coming from more leaned back platformer experiences. 

What makes Hollow Knight compelling: a very simple game loop crafted to perfection. What initially looks like a tiny map due to your limited abilities, knowledge and skill opens up to become one of the most interconnected and challenging world filled with interesting ideas tied together by a mysterious story.
Everything is a bug that wants to hit you. But no scenario feels the same. The design potential has been explored to it's fullest! The art work is stunning, the music is immersive. And the boss fights are pure fun. You will die a lot, but every boss has learnable patterns that can be defeated with the right strategy and enough will-power.

But the true genius is how due to the metroidvania gatekeeping the devs managed to encourage backtracking, promoting intrinsically motivated navigation and exploration of new areas necessary to progress the story, without showing one quest marker the entire game. 

I am sitting at 63% completion and I am aiming for the 110% completion achievement: gonna squeeze every last bit of fun out of this masterpiece! I would have loved a dialogue journal, to catalog and review collected inscriptions and dialogue pieces. I have played the game disconnected over multiple weeks, so I often lost the "flow". But this is my only critique. Bravo!

I learned to like this game.

I did not fall in love with this game immediatelly like thousands of others did. I despise many aspects of the game. Most of all - exploration. The map is hard. I could not remember places I already visited. Halls look all the same. I felt like I was wandering around same places all the time, not knowing where to go next. In early game, death was very punishing and unmotivating.

I did no finish my first playthrough. Few months later, I came back and this time I decided to ditch exploration. I simply followed a guide on IGN and followed recommended path. I also installed VanillaMap mod and simply revealed whole map and items. Second mod I used was enemy HP bar. Now we are talking. Suddenly, I enjoyed everything, fights, progression, platforming.

And then comes the best part. Colloseums and Pantheons. I spent a quarter of the game only on these. For me, this was the best part. Fights and battles unlike anything else I have experienced. I have to tell, getting the last % of 112% in the fouth pantheon drove me crazy. But beating this felt the most rewarding in a long time.

Hollow Knight is a huge game. I still recommend it for everyone, but you may need to pick parts you like. There is plenty to pick from.

Hollow Knight was truly my favorite game I‚Äôve ever played. Even though it is by far not the game I‚Äôve spent the most hours in, it is the one I‚Äôve enjoyed my time in the most. The exploration is perfect, allowing for multiple different through the world which helps make subsequent playthroughs more enjoyable. The world is just generally very beautiful, especially in areas like Fog Canyon and Crystal Peak. The bosses are my absolute bosses in any game I‚Äôve ever played. The thing that made me realize this was my favorite game was getting destroyed by Grimm for the first time. After that, my favorite bosses became Pure Vessel and Nightmare King Grimm. One of the best things about the bosses is the soundtracks. The soundtracks in this game are truly amazing, and my favorite of any game, whether they are for bosses or just for regular areas. 
Beating pantheon 5 was the single most memorable and happy moment of all of my time gaming, and if you haven‚Äôt done so yet I would highly recommend you try it because it feels so incredibly rewarding. Overall, this game is a 10/10, and is far better than Silksong. If you are thinking about buying this game or Silksong, buy this game. I promise you it is much better for new players, but also just in every aspect.
