Got hollow knight a long time ago, got stuck in the forgotten crossroads, didn't play the game for ages, Silksong releases, decides to get hollow knight again. Makes it to greenpath. so far loving the game. 140 hours later, Absolutely love the game but stuck on pantheon 4 :(

'Recommended, BUT...' sort of deal.

Hollow Knight is a boss battler that identifies as a metroidvania. You play as THE Hollow Knight himself as you walk (eventually repeatedly dodge-dash) slowly through all sorts of dingy caverns, slashing away at all sorts of heinous invertebrate beasts with your toothpick. Normally i'd make a cheesy plot summary here but i'm not really sure if there was one since the dialogue requires an English Lit degree to decipher. Or, at least not playing after a long day.

As the game tries to be a Metroidvania (named for its expansive, maze-like map structure separated into 'areas', and backtrack focused design), 100% of what you'll be doing is exploring, slashing, and backtracking to gain an ability that allows you to overcome terrain obstacles and move to the next area. Eventually, you unlock an area focused around [spoiler] refighting bosses you've defeated [/spoiler], which is where i imagine the actual game takes place.

I'm just going to get the good stuff out of the way first. This game really excels in two areas: The boss battles, and the voice acting and sound direction, might just be the most masterful and memorable of any game i've ever played, and i don't say that lightly. The bosses in particular require close observation, patience, practice and skill. The visuals are fine, good even at points, for a 2D game.

Everything else, though, drags the game down far enough that i really want to mark this as a 'not recommended'. Despite everything i'm about to get into, i do feel that the game is just about too well made for that.

As a metroidvania, it's very [strike] hollow [/strike] barebones as many standards of the genre are absent. There are very few [spoiler] traversal upgrades [/spoiler] , and when you do get one, there are very few places to actually use it for anything. The map is small, movement is very slow, and [spoiler] this is not upgraded at any point [/spoiler] , so the world feels like an absolute slog to get through. There are no alternative weapon options [spoiler] and nail upgrades are limited to strength increases; they absolutely just leave you with your little toothpick the whole time [/spoiler]. You have basic directional projectiles and can heal but no other, interesting magic options. There's no equipment, alchemy, stat increases, stats [i] to [/i] increase, buffs, consumable items, or really any interesting or unique collectables. You pretty much end the game in the same state as you started it.

Some of these things are instead included in the 'charm' system. These give you bonuses or upgrades, but only a few can be equipped at a time, with each one having a different number of 'slots' it fills. This works really well for the bosses, as you can mix and match charms to create different builds to take in... but it singlehandedly kills the remaining 98% of the game as [spoiler] many of your upgrades, including those to movement, melee and ranged attacks, soul, all sorts that would be expected as just normal upgrades in any typical metroidvania to make traversal fun, or bearable in this case, are limited to only 2 or 3 at a time [/spoiler]. Even then there's still plenty that's missing.

If i've earned an upgrade that makes traversal bearable, why should i have to leave it off so i can keep using another upgrade that makes traversal bearable, when i could use both and make traversal fun, even? I think either the charms should've used an on/off system and the notch system saved for the boss rebattle modes, or [spoiler] a lot of the charms should've just been standard upgrades like these abilities/upgrades are in any other metroidvania [/spoiler] , and then bosses rebalanced around these. That would go a long way to improving the sense of growth and progression, and making the game feel a bit more fleshed out without any of those other metroidvania staples i mentioned. That's just what i think, anyway.

There are also a few other questionable decisions; My main one is how you can't reach full completion in one playthrough, or even by just taking your time and trying to enjoy the game. Not only because achievements include multiple instances of speedrunning, permadeath modes, and even one of a branching path near the end i think, but because there are some permanently missable things that count to full completion!! There's also the [spoiler] Colosseum of Fools, which is great and enjoyable, it's just that it's in an area which is supposed to be devoid of civilisation and it's full of excited spectators [/spoiler]. It's just a bit immersion breaking. [spoiler] I think it should've been closer to Dirtmouth, but not accessible until the same sort of time as usual. [/spoiler] As i mentioned before, the dialogue is also quite difficult to follow, which makes the plot, lore, worldbuilding, etc. a bit blurry. I had a few more nitpicks but i think i've made my point. I can't remember them right now so they can't be that important.

If you like replayability or boss battles and don't mind at least one 30+ hour slog, pick it up next time it's half off and you'll probably feel it's worth it. If you're a completionist, after a metroidvania, or like to move on after beating the final boss, definitely give this one a miss; you'll probably just end up annoyed or disappointed.

Came back to leave a review after completing Silksong. I found Hollow Knight really hard to stick with and dropped it multiple times before finally finishing it prior to playing Silksong. 

My biggest complaint is that the storytelling is super vague and expects the player to pick up a big chunk of even the main storyline from environmental clues that aren't necessarily easy to make sense of. I can see how this method of storytelling appeals to people, but it's definitely not my cup of tea, and I struggled to maintain interest. I powered through the game and even after getting the "true" ending, still felt like I didn't really understand what is going on at all until I watched a video explaining everything which, looking back, I would never have been able to pick up myself.

Storytelling aside, the combat felt really one-dimensional. Having played Nine Sols before and Silksong after, I can't help but find Hollow Knight's combat system and boss fights lacking and boring, mostly relying on positioning and avoiding enemy attacks with a jump and a simple dash. While I understand that HK's combat is designed and balanced around enemies inflicting touch damage, I'm not a big fan of it, and found that bosses who rely on killing the player with them accidentally running into it are generally just less fun than bosses with more complex skill/movesets. And while Silksong has the same exact system, the combat just feels more fun and rewarding because of how fluid Hornet moves, and the addition of some movement abilities, with the biggest gamechanger being Clawline as a gap-closer or a way to deal with aerial enemies. I understand that Nine Sols has a completely different combat system and it's not fair to compare the combat of the two, but Nine Sols' parry-focused combat is perfect and just feels way way more rewarding than HK's and if you haven't played Nine Sols you should!

Before I start I would like to say that as of time of making this review that I am only 10 hours in.

this My boyfriend got me this game on sale after silk song got released and they were really excited for me to try it. I haven't ever played a metroidvena or whatever its called though I have played Dark Souls 3, Sekiro, Elden Ring, and Lies of P several times so I am familiar with Souls like. 
     What hurts me is that I cannot for the life of me see how/why this game is so praised as the "end all be all" of games. The world is and full of lore and has cute characters, though the levels feel like they go on forever and its the same enemies in each place just swapped out or just a reskin of a previous enemy. 
     The only boss fights I have encountered so far that I actually enjoyed were Hornet, The Soul Master and the Dung Defender. The reason why I liked those fights was because you get to have a 1v1 with a powerful character that doesn't feel like there is other outside bullshit trying to hit you, the reason why i like Dung Defender even though he throws random bullshit at you (literally) is because it only lasts for like...5 seconds? and they don't feel so hard to dodge.
     Characters like The Broken Vessel feel fine until you see that those orange fucks spawn in just to fuck with you piecing him up because he is honest to god, pretty easy. I am on my first play through and killed him first try even with having my soul container broken due to my shadow being elsewhere.
     Another character, The Watcher Knights. This is the boss where I had to put down my keyboard (yes, I use keyboard and mouse instead of a controller, I did the same to the previous games too) and turn off the game. The Watcher Knights suffer from being easy, though by lack of imagination have to add another one with unpredictable A.I. that roll at you at speeds of mach fuck. Now, you might be asking. [i] wait! didn't Dark Souls 3 have the Abyss Watchers? [/i] Well. The thing with the Abyss watchers is that, Yes. There are several bullshit factors that make the fight more difficult, though they are mitigated by the fact that other Abyss Watchers fight the main Boss in his second form, which gives you ample time to fight the weak one that is on your ass so you can beat up the actual boss...with The Watcher Knights it is clearly copy and paste. I haven't beaten them yet, so I am unsure if the boss fight gets better or worse. Though, Jesus Christ? 
     I was semi okay with the Mantis lords being like this due to the fact that they pretty much mimicked each other, sorta like pontiff sulyvahn from Dark Souls, though yet again the mantis lords can be summed up with "Here is the first one, now do it again lmao but with another one of those bug bastards, get fucked buddy." And they don't even have different designs or move sets? The Mantis Lords and The Watcher Knights, like I said, are copy and paste just to make the fight harder without having to actually design the bosses to be hard. There is so much lore to this world that I don't understand though I can feel around me, that was carefully put together. Though, when it comes to the boss fights in the mid game it just feels so lazy and actively makes me want to play other games.

     Honestly this can probably be summed up to "skill issue" which, I'll accept my fate to. Though I will not rate this game poorly because I have not finished it. When I finish this game I will make an edit at the bottom of this review to continue my thoughts, or to eat my words. I do hope that this game gets better, I actively want to like it and be a fan boy like my boyfriend though it is difficult trying to enjoy this game compared to other Souls likes I have. 

Edit: I have now 14 hours in the game and have completed it. 

I am glad that the mid game just had horrid bosses, though perhaps this game suffered from getting in too late and leaving too early. I liked the boss fight at the end, though it really feels like half of the bosses in this game just is really lazily done in my opinion. 
Like I said before, this was a gift from my boyfriend. I haven't hardly seen any gameplay of Hollow Knight until now since ive been playing it. My boyfriend and Others said that the boss fights were really a highlight in this game though after completing it I feel let down. Perhaps I was looking at this game to hard from the standpoint of a Souls-like enjoyer, maybe this game completes itself by being a good metroidvania? perhaps. this is the only metriodvania type game I have ever played so I have zero reference of what a good one is.

Though to finish it off I think this game was fine I suppose, I still don't get the hype of some people regarding this game though to each their own I suppose.
I can see why this is the Game of the Year 2017. Team Cherry a great indie Aussie developer has made an excellent game. I'm enjoying every minute. Including all my deaths and loss of 1400 geo.

THIS GAME GAME IS ASS

The game does a wonderful job of keeping you entertained throughout the entire experience. The boss designs are awesome, with perfectly calculated attack patterns and styles. The animations, and everything else you can think of, are done perfectly.

I finished the game in 32 hours, though I have to admit the last few hours were a bit boring. This was because I saved all the grinding for the end and did all the fun parts first. As someone who gave up on the game across four different saves, believe me when I say: buy this game. Even if you finished a cracked version, go and buy it to support the developers.

I also want to mention that the game isn't as hard as streamers make it seem. Like I said, everything is calculated perfectly. The game doesn't throw impossible fights at you; instead, it gives you limited opportunities and lets you explore. It won't let you kill the final boss right away, but it lets you push your limits as much as you can.

For example, at the start of the game, you'll see a [spoiler]Grub.[/spoiler] There are three ways to reach it:

You can pogo off a fly in the room.

You can wait, return after you've obtained the [spoiler]Mantis Claw.[/spoiler]

You can wait even longer, after getting the Monarch Wings, to save the [spoiler]Grub.[/spoiler]

The game never forces you to play one way. This is a very simple example, but the game does this so well that you often feel like there are no limitations.

Also, since some streamers make the [spoiler]Path of Pain[/spoiler] look incredibly hard‚Äîit's not. It took me about 40-45 minutes to beat. For context, I sometimes struggle with basic platforming even with the [spoiler]Wings and Claw![/spoiler]

Anyway, dude, just go and buy it. It's awesome.

Precept Three: 'Always Be Rested'. Fighting and adventuring take their toll on your body. When you rest, your body strengthens and repairs itself. The longer you rest, the stronger you become.

Precept Four: 'Forget Your Past'. The past is painful, and thinking about your past can only bring you misery. Think about something else instead, such as the future, or some food.

Precept Twenty-Seven: 'Eat As Much As You Can'. When having a meal, eat as much as you possibly can. This gives you extra energy, and means you can eat less frequently.

Precept Thirty-Four: 'Don't Eat Immediately Before Sleeping'. This can cause restlessness and indigestion. It's just common sense.

Precept Thirty-Nine: 'Eat Quickly and Drink Slowly'. Your body is a delicate thing and you must fuel it with great deliberation. Food must go in as fast as possible, but fluids at a slower rate.

Precept Forty-Four: 'You Can Not Breathe Water'. Water is refreshing, but if you try to breathe it you are in for a nasty shock.

Precept Fifty-Five: 'Bow to No-one'. There are those in this world who would impose their will on others. They claim ownership over your food, your land, your body, and even your thoughts! They have done nothing to earn these things. Never bow to them, and make sure to disobey their commands.

I don't know, I had heard a lot about how great the game was. Not sure if that's because my expectations were just too high, but I didn't understand most mechanics in the game, especially when it comes to combat. I thought for some time what rating to give to the game. I can't say it's a bad game. It still has great moments and it definitely found its audience, but it annoyed me too often, which led to a negative overall impression.

[b]Pros[/b]:
- [b]World[/b] is the strongest part of the game. I think this is the reason why everyone loves the game. It is fun to explore overall, especially once you unlock all abilities. The world contains a huge number of secrets and nuances e.g., entire locations could be hidden. Though I don't think some of them are fair or consistent. Usually there's something to give you a hint, but occasionally there are, like, floors/walls without any indications that there's something under/behind them. But I'd say at some point you will need to google anyway. I believe this is forgivable for this game since it is almost impossible to find all secrets by yourself.
- Quite interesting [b]lore[/b] and [b]atmosphere[/b].

[b]Cons[/b]:
- [b]Bosses[/b]. 80% of damage comes from contact damage when they make a sudden sidestep. 
[i]I don't think that's a good way to make a battle difficult[/i]. I would understand if bosses had a rich move set, but usually it's just 2-3 moves and the bosses rapidly move around the arena and damage you with their body. So the boss fights in most cases don't feel fun at all.
- [b]Flying/teleporting enemies[/b]. I cannot describe how I hate fighting them. It feels like you don't have enough means to confront them. They either constantly fly away from you and you have to catch up to try to get them or when trying to run by and ignore them, they simply overtake and contact damage you. Both behavior models are very annoying. The worst part is that there are quite a lot of them. To finish you off, when you hit them, you push them away, beginning the cycle again.
- [b]Tempo[/b]. The game slows you down a lot for some reason. You can't constantly keep going, there's always something that makes you wait. Especially when you need to go down with a lot of spikes on platforms or enemies and you need to constantly check if there is something below, and you're going to go down a lot. And if you get hit by a spike you get respawned unpredictably, so for the first a couple of seconds you spend to understand where you are. Elevators are personally painful with spikes on top, you can't simply jump down, so you have to call it first, wait, and then go down. There are also enemies designed to block your way or overtake you quickly to do so. At first it could be fun and you could spend a lot of time on each thing on your way, but eventually it becomes a routine and a pain in the ass.
- [b]Another boss attempt[/b]. Usually, you need to run one hell of a long way to make another try to kill a boss and with the environment forcefully slowing you down, it can be annoying e.g., [spoiler]the 2nd fight with Hornet[/spoiler], there's a long arena with nothing but a few ledges which don't let you use your flight so you have to just run there. And once you arrive there's often an unskippable animation before the fight and you have to watch them over and over. I've heard this is even worse in the sequel and I truly don't understand why it is supposed to be fun in any way.
- [b]General combat issues[/b]. It could be applied to all the points above. There're often situations when you don't know about enemies but they know about you. So they could attack you behind the screen. It is a regular situation and it is no fun. They could also just run away from you to where you can't see them and then contact damage you. So you often cannot play proactively meaning you have to wait, wait and wait for your enemies to do something before doing something yourself to be sure. Plus, many enemies like shooting homing projectiles going through walls that can get you by surprise and that feels very cheap.
- [b]Controls[/b]. They don't feel responsive sometimes, like there is no buffer for what you just pressed. Feels like there's a small delay after your input before you can input again. I often encountered situations where my inputs were just ignored without any visible reason why. I don't like it. I also had a problem with unintentionally triggered double jumps near corners or walls.

[b]Cons[/b] but debatable:
- [b]Abilities[/b]. I am sure some people may like it, but for me it was too slow and disappointing. What you get right away in most games, you have to slowly discover here, like double jumps, wall jumps, or a dash. Most games come with something interesting to stop you from going further, but here it is this simple. And often the game stops your progress with just a slightly bigger gap so you can't jump over it with your normal jump. It didn't feel rewarding for me, more like I was given back what I was supposed to have had to overcome something insignificant.

Initially picking up this game in Oct. 2024, I spent about 45 hours slowly exploring and figuring things out myself, getting to 80 percent outside of the titular boss arena.

After a 10-month break, the initial plan was to finally look up online hints and guides to take care of some minor side quests and hidden rooms -- nothing serious or difficult. This got old quickly and I considered fighting the titular boss and ending the game. But then I had the thought: "I wonder what that White Palace is like. Guess I'll have to fight the 'dream' bosses." This was the literal game changer.

From there, I began looking up different charm builds and combat strategies, whereas previous I just compiled and did things haphazardly. After dispatching each of the dream bosses, it was the brutal punishing platforming of the White Palace. While in the White Palace, I once again had the thought, "I wonder what the Path of Pain is like." Twenty-plus hours* of frustration, cursing, wanting to quit, and literal pain, that, too was dispatched. But I wasn't done yet.

One thing turned into another: "I wonder what the Colosseum of Fools is like"; "I wonder what the Grimm Troupe DLC is like"; "I wonder how to complete the Delicate Flower side quest," and so on. Each of these I completed, not efficiently, but I was locked in. When I thought I had finally beat the game by dispatching the titular boss, the Internet informed me after the fact of the real final boss: the Radiance. Even though I thought I was done, I just couldn't live with myself knowing the actual final boss hadn't been defeated. After some more hours of frustration, cursing, wanting to quit, and literal pain, the Radiance was finally defeated. This was last night.

At 108 percent and 108 hours**, as someone who went from almost "calling it good" to beating the Path of Pain, entire Colosseum of Fools, entire Grimm Troupe story line while beating Nightmare King Grimm in a wrist brace (thanks again, Path of Pain), attaining all the charms, masks, and shards, and beating the Radiance (again in a wrist brace), I am quite satisfied with my "Hollow Knight" experience. 

Recognizing my mental and physical limitations, I will regard the Pantheons with wonder and admiration. Major props to those who attempt these gauntlets, and major kudos to those who can beat them. As for me, I'll take my impulsive over-achievement and look forward to the next installment.

*Offline play not factored in to overall Steam runtime (don't like my Internet on while sleeping).

Hollow Knight is an incredible game, beautifully made, challenging, and absolutely worth the effort. The world is rich with lore, and even though the story and backstory are quite depressing, the game itself is stunning to experience. Some of the area soundtracks are just fantastic.

The difficulty does ramp up later, and the DLCs and endgame are definitely tough, which can be demotivating for some players. I have had moments where I just wanted to quit, but the lore, story, and sheer depth of the game kept me going. The multiple endings were a great bonus too, and it all felt worth it in the end.

For the price Team Cherry asks, it offers way more content than you would expect. Easily one of the best metroidvania games ever made.

over the years i have bought many games, and many of those i did not finish. It was an incredible experience that may or may not have garnered a few moments of rage but none the less it was an amazing purchase and a game well worth playing.

I am now off to my next adventure in Hollow Knight: Silksong

I got this game recommended to me by an old friend. At first when he told me to play it, I gave it a try. Got all the way to city of tears but it just didnt click for me. He knew I loved souls games so after a while, maybe a year, he told me to try it again. This time the game just clicked in my head. The world pulled me in, the seemingly simplistic combat felt satisfying and the exploration felt very rewarding. There was something useful to be found in every corner of the map. And the more i explored the more i liked it. 

Now hollow knight still isnt a game I would usually play, Im not a very big fan of metroidvania souls likes. But after getting a few endings and seeing about 85% of the game at the time of writing, I can see why its praised and prized by its fans. Hollow knight is definitely an experience I wont forget even if I dont like it as I do other souls games. And its definitely a game thats worth the price tag.

I should mention I played this on Switch, but I'll review here. Absolutely fantastic game. I was more impressed by the story telling than I thought I would be going through this game (for the 2nd time for Silksong, and I paid closer attention this time around). When it all comes together the story leaves you thinking for awhile about it, which are my favorite types of stories.

If you like Metroidvanias or Souls-like at all, it's a must play, but I'm preaching to the choir a bit. Great exploration, simple combat yet provides plenty of challenge with several bosses, and the freedom to explore where and when you want. 

Music also absolutely fantastic, and used excellently throughout the game, especially at the end to enhance the story telling along with the player's actions. Truly a master piece of a game.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

The things I'd give to replay this masterpiece again for the first time... 

If you want a game that makes you feel things. ranging from being amazed, to being lost, and bashing your head against the wall, then, this is the one.

On a serious note, everything about this game is just great. Music? Phenomenal. Atmosphere? Likewise. Story? Tear shedding. Art style? Just perfect.

Almost every boss is fair and makes you think that it was your fault for losing. The bosses are fun, challenging, and rewarding.

Even if you beat the game normally, there are many more things you can do. There are many endings to get, story to uncover, charms to collect, quests to finish, and, of course, fight the freaking sun.

I can't believe this work of art was made by 3 people, major companies could never. 

Would recommend and glaze until the day I die.

Despite the age of this game, the art-style and mechanics of Hollow Knight will always keep the game high, 
Every area is different with loads of effort put into each area with different paths and enemies to keep the play-through fresh. 
The bosses aren't too difficult and only take time to learn how they play and move, and once you figure that out it gets easy and potentially even enjoyable to finally defeat that one boss that you always struggled on.

There wasn't any game breaking bugs and I absolutely adored the whole journey I've part took in this and would recommend it to anyone who wants to start a fresh game that is a bit different.

Hollow Knight is one of the finest 2D platformers ever made. Combat feels smooth and satisfying, with each boss battle testing your patience and precision. The normal bosses are well-balanced and easier to read, while the Dream bosses push your reflexes to the limit, offering thrilling and challenging fights.

Exploration is the heart of the game ‚Äî from the eerie depths of the Forgotten Crossroads to the regal heights of the White Palace, every location feels alive and mysterious. There‚Äôs no right or wrong path ‚Äî just explore, and you‚Äôll constantly discover new secrets, shortcuts, and surprises.

Geo farming feels natural rather than grindy, as enemies, colosseum battles, and exploration all reward you consistently. Charms and spell upgrades add meaningful customization, and spells themselves can devastate mini-bosses with the right build. The Path of Pain stands as the ultimate platforming challenge for those who crave mastery.

With a beautiful soundtrack, emotional NPC stories, and smooth traversal upgrades, Hollow Knight never stops rewarding your curiosity. Even after 100+ hours for full 112% completion, it remains satisfying from start to finish. For its low price (around $4 on sale), the sheer content, polish, and atmosphere make it a must-play.

Team Cherry created not just a game, but an experience that defines what a perfect Metroidvania should be. Looking forward to diving into your second masterpiece, Silksong, soon.

Overall Score: 10/10

Not gonna lie, the game starts off almost tedious. There is no handholding and by sheer dumb luck I went into all the wrong directions first (and there is quite a few) until I could finally proceed. Once you unlock the first movement ability, the game starts opening up. Though the game seems seems kind of simplistic early on, it gets really tough later on with a lot of challenges if you're up for it. 

Exploration is rewarded and you'll need to master the combat and movement system to be really efficient. 

The atmosphere is dense and the game's vibe ranges from sorta gothic cute to creepy horror, the soundtrack is fantastic and I adore the voice work (the grub cheer is my new notification sound). 

A really nice gaming experience! Tough, but rewarding.
Highly recommended!

I love this game so much I'm not quite sure how to put it into words. 

I started playing this game on my PS4, and it hooked me with the deep story, grappling gameplay and stunning art (both music and visual). Sure, the very first part of the game can seem boring, and I know that's when most players quit. But I loved this game so much that when I got it on Steam, I had no disappointment replaying the game from square zero (I loved it). Combined with this game's well-thought out narrative, stunning soundtrack and beautiful art, the game play spans around 30 hours of fun in the core narrative and a whole 80 or so for players who want to take it further (like me). I have about 200 hours on this game at time of review (about 120 on my PS4) and I still have some extra hard challenges I can do. 

This is a must-play for almost everyone (it's also only 15 USD).

I don't care what anyone says, the map design in this game is atrocious and the amount of backtracking is simply mindblowing, the game deserves a downvote just based on that. 

I don't generally mind a bit of backtracking and I can appreciate non-linear games, but here we only get an illusion of non-linearity since there is only one actual path that you need to take to progress further, you just don't know it until you find it. This leads you to taking the wrong turns constantly as you try to find the one and only path, which means endlessly reclearing the same corridors. Now, this wouldn't be that bad if there was a good mini-map, markers or landmarks that would help you get your bearings, but no - there is nothing of the sort, instead you get various shades of gray as you traverse the Same Corridor #69420 for the 10th time. It also wouldn't be that bad if going off the only and only path was rewarding in ANY way, but in 99% of cases you will get nothing or a few geos.

All that directly links with the second point that is constant backtracking, which can be somewhat limited if you already KNOW when and where you'll get a certain feature that you'll need to unlock certain doors or collect certain items, but when you're playing for the first time? Yeah, have fun (you won't).

Not in a single other game have I ever complained about boss runbacks. This one takes the cake, I just can't be bothered. And all enemies dealing damage on contact, even if it's a midget standing still, just doesn't sit right with me, purely subjective. I can sing songs to all other aspects of the game, but others did it better. I tried it, and no amount of artistic beauty and otherwise well polished gameplay could make running to a boss that is physically 50m away, but takes a few dozen turns and twists to get to, fun.

Maybe I could grit my teeth and power through it, but I don't feel inclined in the slightest.

This game is an absolute masterpiece! From the moment you descend into Hallownest, the world feels hauntingly alive, yet dead.. every shadow, echo, and background flicker of light adds to the eerily lonely atmosphere. The artstyle stunningly portrays ruin and beauty in equal measure, creating a world that feels both abandoned and strangely sacred. And the soundtrack!.. soft piano, somber strings, and the swelling orchestral moments perfectly encapsulate the loneliness and sense of wonder. This is an experience that stuck with me long after the credits rolled.

Quiero aclarar que soy de latinoamerica, y no se como sea en otras regiones pero aqui la pirateria es muy comun. Este es el juego que realmente me ha echo entender el valor de un producto, por este juego he dejado la pirateria, silksong ha sido el primer juego que he comprado en mi vida despues de jugar una version pirata de hollow knight y ahora despues de desinstalar la copia pirata estoy comprando la version oficial, este juego me ha hecho entender que un vifeojuego es mas que un producto, es arte, es un sue√±o de alguian que alguien tuvo e hizo realidad, es el trabajo de una o muchas personas, esto es lo que he comprendido luego de jugar hollow knight, ahora he desninstalado todas las aplicaciones piratas que poseia (no solo los juegos) y he empezado a comprar algunos y los que faltan los he puesto en una wishlist, y cada que compro uno es un sentimiento de regocijo infinito. Hoy puedo decir que hollow knight  ha cambiado mi vida y mi forma de ver los videojuegos y todos los productos digitales.

It's a great game with amazing visuals. The first 80% is generally fantastic, with very few stinkers in between the bosses. The lategame though? No thanks. Bosses spam attacks, there's a bunch of crap flying around and there are no clear gaps in their attacks which can be exploited without taking damage. If you don't mind spending 10 hours learning unfair bossfights to actually progress the story, go ahead. It's not for me. The last good fight I fought was the hollow knight, completing the normal game. For the last 32% with alternative endings, it's just not worth it. It's a grind, it's a slog, it's boring, it's annoying and it just feels like they ran out of ideas and compensate for this with more projectiles and bigger hitboxes that effectively make pogo and dash not viable. In this sense I guess I was hoping it was more like Blasphemous lategame. Extremely difficult, but mostly fair and skill based. I hope silksong is better.

Still, amazing value for money. I just don't want to spend days training muscle memory to fight a boss. It's no longer a skill issue at that point, you're learning all the attack patterns to pixel perfection because that's the only way to win. Either that or give up and spam spells. Not my thing.

I love this game, which should be evident by my 750 hours playing it. It's difficult, but with practice I'm able to develop strategies to beat the bosses. Learn when and how to dodge, when to make your attacks. Silksong is similar, but ramps up difficult by requiring fast reaction times, which I don't have, possibly because of my age. So, while Silksong has improvements over this original, I think this game is a masterpiece, while Silksong is reducing its target audience at a smaller percentage of gamers that excludes me.

Hollow Knight is a precision-focused Metroidvania set in the ruined insect kingdom of Hallownest. Exploration drives the entire structure. The map unfolds through deliberate navigation, hidden paths, and gradual acquisition of movement abilities. The pacing is controlled and rewards careful observation.

Combat is simple but demanding. The nail provides short-range attacks with tight timing windows. Enemies telegraph patterns clearly, so success depends on spacing and discipline. Boss fights escalate this design. They test pattern recognition and consistent execution rather than stat-based power.

Progression relies on ability upgrades and charm loadouts. Abilities unlock new regions, while charms modify combat, mobility, or survivability. The system allows meaningful customization without excess complexity. Builds remain readable and grounded.

The world is delivered through environmental storytelling. NPCs appear sparingly and provide limited guidance. Most narrative context comes from ruins, encounters, and implied history. This creates a quiet tone and a sense of discovery without direct exposition.

Art direction is hand-drawn and sharp. Regions differ in color, architecture, and enemy behavior. Animations are clean and readable, which matters for precise combat. Visual contrast ensures threats remain identifiable even in dense areas.

Audio design defines atmosphere. The soundtrack uses subdued piano, strings, and ambient layers. Sound cues mark enemy actions and hazards with clarity. The mix preserves informational signals during high-intensity fights.

Hollow Knight succeeds through tight controls, disciplined world design, and restrained storytelling. It offers long exploration, high mechanical challenge, and strong environmental identity. Players who value precision and deliberate pacing receive a consistent, well-structured experience.

I'll start first by saying that this game IS compatible with the PS5 controller, in case anyone is wondering. But lets get to the game.

Gorgeous. 
So simple yet so alive in every aspect. The movement feels natural. The enemies feel like they belong where they are. The combat is very challenging, but rewarding all the same. The story is dark and nuanced with hints being left all over filling in blanks, but also raising more questions. Every mechanic is meticulously crafted and balances itself. The limited upgrades work well with having to equip different charms as to fit different scenarios, bosses, or other situations. The free roaming and exploring getting lost and discovery is satisfying. 

Absolute wonderful game.

At first I was captivated by the amazing artstyle of the game, it‚Äôs beyond beautiful.
But the playstyle‚Ä¶ well, I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs a matter of both taste and experience. When I first started playing I was absolutely horrible at everything I tried to do, I haven‚Äôt played neither metroidvanias nor many platformers before attempting to play this game and it surely was visible in how I attempted everything‚Ä¶
So I took a break from it, a rather long one at that, and I came back after playing some simpler games of the sort aaaand the comeback was much more pleasant than the first attempt. I still wasn‚Äôt too good at it, but slightly less frustrated about that fact, so I tried again and again, slowly watching myself getting a better grasp of the mechanics.
Along the way, I inevitably fell in love with every little aspect of this game, especially the amazing (and sad) lore.

Maybe it‚Äôs not a game for everyone, but it sure is worth giving a try!

What can I say that hasn't already been said when I'm this late to the game? (Played it throughout October of 2025.)

The dark atmosphere is top notch, and so are the boss designs. It's tough and punishing, but it felt much more fair than a lot of its more recent copycats.

Nightmare Grimm aside, beating a difficult boss was usually a matter of taking some time to calm down and find my focus. Attacks are mostly well-signaled, and getting through them is a matter of not making (too many) mistakes.

Bosses also didn't feel as damage-spongy as a lot of what Metroid Dread had on offer.

This is a great one! I'll get to Silksong before long! (But I still need to give the Pantheon content a proper try here.)

Legitimately one of the worst games I've ever played. Terrible mechanics, unfair fights, horrible performance on a high end PC that makes these unbearably stupid fights even worse than I could ever possibly imagine. Im glad I didnt pay for this game because id be really mad at myself. This game seems to have been designed with a literal disdain for anyone who dared waste $20 on it. The "fast travel" system is a joke. You spend more time trying to get back to where you thought you should have been going than you do actually playing the fucking game. I think my favorite part is the input lag in a game that requires really precise timing on certain things. Without mods I would have put this game down after about 5 hours. Being forced to spend a notch point on a compass or picking up currency might be one of the most braindead things in this game besides the fact that you cant just simply teleport between save benches. Seriously, team cherry, eat a bag of dicks. This isn't fun hard like Elden ring, this is just stupid, poorly designed and poorly performing hard. I seriously do not understand the fanfare for this game.

This game is not a metroidvania, it's a 2D RPG. 

The core gameplay loop is about killing enemies, farming currency, and then buying upgrades, to kill more enemies and get more currency/better gear. It is very much not about exploring so you can find things to explore more. 

There's [i]very[/i] few movement unlocks, and tragically little to discover outside of currency for such a large map. The map also unfolds incredibly linearly for the first 75% of the game which is not ideal. 

A lot of people love this game, and I presume it has a lot to offer for RPG fans, showcasing what can be done in the 2D genre. 

But if you're a core Metroidvania 2D exploration kind of fan, this may not be for you. It certainly has not been all that enjoyable for me.

hollow knight is a metroidvania, so it has backtracking.
the combat feels good, the platforming is fun, (except [spoiler] path of pain [/spoiler] ) progression is well paced.

Team Cherry is trying to make good, quality games at a $20 base price. honestly, you should buy this game solely on the premise of that. 

However, if you're not familiar with platforming, I encourage you to get an introduction with Ori and the Blind Forest and especially Ori and the Will of the Wisps because Will of the Wisps took *heavy* inspiration from Hollow Knight. 

so, if you're questioning the crazy getting lost and not knowing what to do, try Ori first, but please please please consider investing in this movement of Team Cherry being goated and based af!!

Hollow Knight is, simply put, a masterpiece. I've played many games before in my (albeit relatively short) life, and this one seems to top them all. At first, I was hesitant to purchase the game due to my unfamiliarity with the metroidvania genre, but the release of Silksong drove me to give it a shot, and I can now confidently say it was worth it.

As one of the few cracks in this otherwise lustrous, perfect gemstone, the game's slow beginning is a small hurdle to overcome prior to enjoying the experience to its full extent; if you're looking to purchase this work, please keep such information in mind. It is undeniable, however, that once in its clutches, Hollow Knight will not let go of your attention with its addictive gameplay loop, intriguing exploration, and thrilling boss fights.

Aditionally, it's worth mentioning that the game has no intent in protecting the player from the consequences of their own actions: misplays will absolutely be met with proportional setback, but the realistic nature of this dynamic makes it all the more satisfying to best Hallownest's challenges. By no means is this a negative point, as long as you remain open-minded and conscient of your own faults.

All in all, the smooth controls, incredible art direction, and amazing game design will have players wishing they could experience it for the first time, a second time. I would recommend this game with no hesitation.

[h1] Preface [/h1]
I took 3 attempts to finally get into the groove with this game. I gave up the first 2 times because I'm not about that metroidvania life - I'd keep roaming around the same 5 places with dead-ends till I go insane, completely clueless about where to go next to unlock the upgrades I need to get past the said dead-ends.

One day I came across a friend on discord who was playing this with a guide - my initial instinct was "isn't that cheating? lol" but his very pragmatic response was simply "No. Guides in these metroidvanias proxy as the where-to-go-next markers you see in most other games." - like an overhead pointer or a marker on the mini map. I realized that using a guide effectively renders HK a part puzzle-platformer + a series of almost soulslike boss fights. Which I can get behind.

[h1] Appreciation [/h1]
I am glad I stumbled upon that VC that fateful day. Now, after having nearly completed this game with IGN's guide on a second screen, I can safely say that this game has [i]by far the most value for money[/i] in a video game I have ever experienced (lightyears far, seriously), nothing even comes close. It is my new favourite game. (Dethroning Arkham Asylum took some beating - it holds a special place in my heart due to fond childhood memories.)

If I knew what I was getting into, I'd have happily paid $60 for the pleasure to wield a nail in this absolutely gorgeous, vast and diverse masterpiece. 

[h1] More on value for money [/h1]
Now that I know what this game is really like, I almost feel guilty for purchasing it on sale. Now I would deliberately wait for a sale to be over to purchase Silksong - I'm beyond certain that that game is also worth more than some EA titles combined.

It is also criminal that [i]they made all DLCs free[/i]. God bless this one studio working wonders while charging 1/3rd of what this game is [i]at least[/i] worth.

Most AAA titles - not just the slop, even the critically acclaimed ones - AND revered indie titles these days cost $30-70 (more for expansions) and sometimes don't last beyond 6 hours, though the average period in my experience tends to be around 12-18 hours for only the single player campaign (excluding side missions, etc). There are some rare standouts that take longer (The WItcher 3, RDR2, Elden Ring, etc.) but even they - indie or AAA - cost $60-70 at full price. This game flies in that face of the whole industry with the value it provides for a modest $15.

What's even more impressive is that the titles I've listed above are critically acclaimed, deeply-cherished-by-the-community ones. Most AAA games these days don't last beyond 16 hrs, nor do they house any real quality. Hollow Knight is so vast, deep, and high-quality - EA would've milked 3-4 games out of this package for $60 each if they were to develop this concept.

The sheer vastness cannot be articulated - you just have to experience it. It'll hit you when, after having explored the first few sections of the map, you venture deeper into hallownest and return to the initial sections at some point. It made my jaw drop with wonder when I reflected "this is all the same game. These sections are not from a prequel, it's all one game I bought for $4."

While I'm not over the moon for this game like most people, I can't really justify giving it the thumbs down either. It's a very playable, pretty fun platformer that has a few flaws that bother me. The graphics are very nice and uniquely Hollow Knight, you won't find another game that looks like it other than its sequel. While the music is iconic and for good reason, I have to knock the sound design a little bit. The game has sound cues for literally everything around you, which gets overwhelming in certain rooms where there are many sound effects all playing over each other at full volume constantly. That may seem like a small issue, but it really takes you out of the game in some areas.

As for the gameplay itself, it's pretty great. The controls are responsive and fluid, with the only trouble I had being with the wall jump not sticking to walls sometimes. None of the movement upgrades you get will blow your mind or anything, but they complement each other very well. When you have your full moveset, going around the more obstacle-heavy rooms really fast certainly makes you feel like a god gamer. The combat is a little bit more limited, though. Aside from a few special attacks you can unlock through the course of the game, the only attacks you're usually left with are your main weapon and a limited use projectile. Thankfully, most of the boss fights are designed with this in mind, giving you ample opportunity to attack. Being able to stagger bosses to give you precious time you can use to use your healing ability, which is slow and leaves you vulnerable, is incredibly smart from a game design standpoint. This game isn't nearly as difficult as it's sometimes described as, at least not if you simply wanna get to the end, and that works in the game's favour in my opinion.

What would've worked better though, is if they ditched the more punishing gameplay elements. Having a very limited healthbar where you need to make space for yourself to recover it is fine, it adds a a little bit more pressure onto the player. Losing all of your money on death and having to chase it down afterwards just does not work in a game like this, though. It's very frustrating if you end up in an area you're not quite ready for yet, die, and have to trudge through there again just to recover all the stuff you've lost. Because the game is all about the exploration aspect, and because you're given very little guidance on where to go next, it's pretty inevitable that this will happen to you at least once on a first playthrough. Traversal also takes longer to get from one end of the map to the other than most games, fast travel is very limited, and certain paths get blocked off over time, which makes the later parts of the game pretty tedious when you have to go around nearly the entire map just to unlock the final boss.

Overall, it's a pretty good game despite my problems with it. I couldn't really find myself caring that much for the lore or anything, there are games in this genre that do it better in my opinion, but I like seeing the memes of it on the social medias so it's all good.

Hollow Knight is such an oddball game to me in the sense that it's an incredible experience when the devs actually design it to challenge you but most of the game is painfully boring.

The spirit mechanic on paper is fine as a conventional meter system but I think the healing mechanic hurts it. I don't like the fact that it allows wreckless play because most enemies aren't actually capable of doing more than one piece of damage to you before they die and the amount of meter you build by attacking them alleviates it quickly. The few enemies that do are usually slow moving big bodies that either can be trivalized with an attack + dash away tactic or you can safely dash over their heads. This wouldn't be so bad if wasn't for the fact that in the moment to moment, enemies don't typically control much space or pose any threat to you through attrition in a way they can in other metroidvanias. It's way too easy to just ignore them 80% of the time. There's also the issue that since healing takes up the spirit meter you're typically discouraged from using any other ability that utilizes that system since the reward and cost of using any ability isn't worth it when keeping yourself alive is far more rewarding. It gets worse with the weird tuning where nail upgrades make bosses have more health which makes your abilities weaker.

The level design is a mix of mostly empty hallways with pits and areas that emphasize verticality. Enemy layouts are cookie cutter, usually 3-4 fodder enemies in a hallway or a few easily ignorable flying enemies in more vertical areas. On the rare occassion you may get an enemy that's good at covering space such as the Soul Twister's but the game rarely feels the need to make enemy encounters threatening. This is probably to make the travel between areas less tedious given how limited the fast travel mechanic is but it still feels like a chore especially with how much gating the game has. This may be a necessity given the scale of the game but it just results in a lot of boring back and forth between areas where you'll often end up ignoring enemies after a certain point.

Aside from this Hollow Knight does offer the occassional platforming setpiece. These are easily more interesting than most of the moment to moment in Hollow Knight but I feel their main issue is that they're usually overly reliant on one ability and are too easily solved. Even still, I'd much prefer this than the norm with Hollow Knight because it's at least making use of certian mechanics. These setpieces are too sparse and usually optional.

The way Hollow Knight presents its map system is pretty unique but I wish they'd commit to it. Very early you get upgrades to transform it into a conventional metroidvania map system when the initial premise is you have no map marker and had to read the layouts yourself. On some level I feel this would have been received poorly by a lot of players and you could make the case that it just adds drudgery to a simple concept, but it just comes off as cowardly to not make this the default experience. The caveat they make for this is not severe enough to matter and in any situation where you might not want the pin for tracking your part of the map is within areas that likely will have a seat for you to change it anyway. 

Hollow Knight's progression is slower than most metroidvanias and that's to its detriment. The game has a lot of bosses but most function under the assumption you only have the dash ability and thus it's a slog to play through because these boss fights are so boring and one note. Too many bosses are overly generous in terms of how big their start up frames are for their attacks and arenas are usually fairly sizable to make dodging them easy. Usually the way bosses are designed in that they focus on one or two attacks and after being hit a number of times they do the attack another time sequentially and I find this boring because you're never changing your solution when engaging with these different phases. What worked the first time is going to work again the second time. It's not until [spoiler]Hollow Knight[/spoiler] where the game's boss fights finally acknowledges that you have more mobility options than just the dash and god I wish the game did this sooner.

Nothing about the plot or lore grabbed me. A lot of it is excessively cryptic and the game doesn't really give you much reason to care or ponder what any specific message means. I guess there's some lore heads who like piecing it together but with the bits I decided to invest in it all came off to me as so tepid and uninspired. The crypticness has a purpose in defining its overall vibe but the game didn't sell me enough on its vibe for me to care.

I completed the game within 20 hours and I was under the impression that the post-game wasn't inviting anything valuable to engage with. But my peers insisted I try it out and well... I gotta it admit it changed my perspective of the game.

The Trial of fools is a damn solid gauntlet that actually had me thinking about the utility of my arts and it's also a case where the specific point you decide to do it changes the experience. Not having the shade cloak; for example, has you thinking about enemies in a very different way. I also love that it tightens the space for certain enemies, making you far more thoughtful about your movement options. It can be a bit tiring to go through multiple attempts given that you might be only filtered by one part of the gauntlet and the rest of it ends up feeling tedious but I respect the game demanding that level of consistency from you.

The White Palace convinced me that Hollow Knight has merit as a platformer. This is the only case where I felt the game was making me utilize multiple different mechanics and also allowing for ways to approach challenges in unorthodox ways. I think what I like about it too is how it shows the flexibility of the dash button given that it's useful for both platforming and combat. Combining that with the double jump is such a satisfying way to get over obstacles. It was so cool seeing the boost ability be utilized here in the way it was as well, given that the main game only really uses it for gating. My only problem with this section is that there are some areas where it obscures sight of a saw hazard and you could get damaged due to lacking the knowledge that it exists in that area. But other than that, a surprisingly well-designed platform level.

The post-game/optional boss fights are so bizarre to me in the sense that they feel alien to how bosses are usually designed in the main game. They're a lot more varied in the type of attacks they use and they'll also utilize multiple attacks at once to cover space. [spoiler]The Radiance[/spoiler] is such a great example of this. But others like Lost Kin use spawning enemies to add challenge too, which they clearly didn't have the balls to do in the main game. I gotta say, when I started the Godhome boss gauntlet it highlighted to me how boring most of the game's bosses are and it made me lose all enthusiasm for doing it.

So it begs the question, why did I put this in "not recommended?" On a certain level, I think Hollow Knight is fantastic. But it's also a case where like... only 10% of the game is actually engaging to me, which is more egregious in how a lot of it is DLC. The game's highs are incredible, but I don't even think the game has lows. It's just consistently boring for most of its playtime. The game has such a strong foundation yet Team Cherry rarely feels compelled to push it, and that's what makes Hollow Knight so disappointing to me.

When I first got Hollow Knight, I genuinely wasn't expecting much. I knew that it is a popular game, but it just didn't seem like my kind of game. I'm into a few rogue-likes/lites, Undertale, and some Nintendo games. When Silksong released and the hype was crazy, I decided to buy Hollow Knight.

I don't think I could have bought a better game with that money.

At first, I thought that it was weird to have an open world sidescroller game, but they actually did a great job making an open world. So far the progression seems very well-paced. I am never bored playing it and I feel like I am unlocking new items at a great pace. The bosses are difficult enough that I'm not breezing through them, but they're not so difficult that I'm getting discouraged (I know, I'm just at the start. I'm aware that I'm fighting the easy bosses). Overall, I would rate the game 9.5/10 because I can't kill that annoying Zote the Mighty guy. [h1] Hollow Knight ‚Äì A Symphony of Silence and Shadows [/h1]

[h2]Art & Atmosphere: The Beauty of Desolation[/h2]
Hollow Knight is not just drawn‚Äîit‚Äôs crafted. Every frame, every wall, every faint glimmer of light in Hallownest feels deliberate, as if painted by a melancholy artist who understands both wonder and grief. Its hand-drawn world breathes with sorrowful elegance, a haunting beauty that lingers in every corridor. Each region‚Äîwhether the forgotten city bathed in rain or the fungal caverns pulsing with quiet life‚Äîhas its own soul, its own story to whisper if you‚Äôre willing to listen.

[h2]World Design: A Maze of Meaning[/h2]
The kingdom of Hallownest is vast, layered, and intricately interwoven. Paths fold into each other with masterful precision, creating a world that feels alive, ancient, and waiting. Every shortcut unlocked, every hidden chamber found feels earned‚Äîa testament to your perseverance and curiosity. Exploration here is not just a mechanic; it‚Äôs a pilgrimage.

[h2]Gameplay & Combat: Precision in Motion[/h2]
Hollow Knight‚Äôs combat is pure rhythm‚Äîgraceful, sharp, and exacting. Every strike, every dodge, every leap carries weight. It‚Äôs not about raw strength, but mastery through understanding. As your abilities grow, so too does your freedom, until movement itself becomes an art form. There‚Äôs poetry in its precision, beauty in its balance. The bosses, too, are lessons in patience and observation: merciless yet fair, demanding respect but offering triumph to those who endure.

[h2]Story & Music: Whispers Beneath the Earth[/h2]
The story is never handed to you‚Äîit‚Äôs found, hidden in the ruins, in forgotten words, in fading memories. Hollow Knight trusts you to piece it together, to see meaning in the silence. The music, composed with haunting restraint, becomes your companion‚Äîa blend of sorrow and serenity that deepens every emotion without a single word spoken.

[h2]Pacing & Patience: The Weight of the Beginning[/h2]
The early hours move slowly, restrained by the limitations of your fragile form. Yet, in that restraint lies purpose. It teaches humility. It asks you to earn your strength, to savor each new ability as liberation. The journey begins with struggle, but ends in transcendence.

[h2]Final Verdict: A Timeless Descent into Beauty[/h2]
Hollow Knight is not merely a game‚Äîit‚Äôs a meditation on persistence, loss, and discovery. It rewards curiosity, punishes arrogance, and quietly teaches resilience. Few games manage to speak so loudly through silence, to build a world so broken yet so full of grace.

Team Cherry didn‚Äôt just make a platformer; they built a world that feels remembered.
A place you don‚Äôt simply play‚Äîyou inhabit, you endure, you fall in love with.

[h2]Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ (Perfect)[/h2]

There are three things I got from buying many Nintendo consoles over the years to play Pokemon games. One - fun from playing Pokemon games, two - zeroing my savings account, three - my love of Metroidvania genre as Metroid and Castlevania were the only worthwhile things beside Pokemon I could play on those consoles.

Hollow Knight is a good game, a monument to indie games and a middle finger to tripple A segment but not exactly best Metroidvania.

Music and sounds are very good and fitting, I have many tracks from it playing frequently in my favorite playlists.

Art design is conceptually unique and flawless aside from colors. 80% of the game is the same, constant mud stain of grey and blue with squint of white and black in it. Some would say it's fitting to the overall game atmosphere and they're not wrong. After all calling it Dark Souls of Metroidvanias or Dark Souls 2D has to come from somewhere.
Sadly unlike Dark Souls and for instance Ender Lillies I found it really boring and tedious after a while. I ended up happy every time I discovered new or revisited one of the more vivid areas like Green Path or Fungal Wastes.

Story is solid but quite fractured. Similar to Souls series by just playing you learn enough to have a general idea with much being unknown,few scraps available via characters dialog, items descriptions etc. and a lot left for speculation. This kind of makes learning the lore a reward and mechanic on itself.

Gameplay wise devs did not invent the wheel anew here, like in every metroidvania you have familiar style map for you to explore and set of abilities like double jump, wall climbing etc. and bosses to kill. What is different is "pogo" tying directly to combat system. 
If you hit an enemy or spike on wall or floor (at least specific type of spike) you get backed off a bit. That allows you to "pogo" yourself through some areas and makes combat more vertical and engaging.

Default difficulty curve if well designed. Don't skip of exploration, getting new skills and upgrades more or less in dev intended way and you'll be fine. At least till the end or till you touch optional bosses. You can always use the equip able charm system to customize your character more closely to the way you like to play which is a nice addition.

Hollow Knight's main two problems are mentioned above "dev intended way" which is hard to identify and somewhat iffy map design. 

Starting with the latter there are three separate systems of fast travel independent of each other. Despite that they're are spread way to thin and scarce making huge portions of the map accessible only through long and tedious backtracking by foot. Benches aka resting spots are fourth, completely separate deal. They're also too few for my liking but would make the game way better if you could just teleport between them instead of additional methods of fast travel.

Now what usually happens when I play new metroidvania game is I'm able to finish it checking the wiki or yt guide if I'm stuck which happens two maybe three times at most. Then I start a new game plus trying achieve 100%, 112% 200% or whatever given tittle offers by freely using wiki and guides.

In Hollow Knight however I had to more than quadruple said first time wiki/yt counter due to the sheer amount to times I was stuck with my head against the wall unable to progress and not knowing what to do or where I'm suppose to go next. That's the most subjective and final part of my review but in my ... well ... opinion something is wrong here.

Great story, a beautiful and charming world, and unforgettable boss fights. These are just some words that can describe Hollow Knight.

This masterpiece reminds you, right at the beginning of the game, how bad you are at orientation, cause let's be honest, everyone got lost in Hallownest at their first playthrough :D. However, when you are patient enough and keep playing, you will discover a whole new small universe in the gaming world, and the hidden, magnificent gem among indie games. If you are a Soulslike enthusiast, you also won‚Äôt regret it, because bosses are hard, yet balanced, and extremely rewarding in the end. Although bosses are tough, you will love fighting them, and the feeling of finishing the boss for the first time is irreplaceable. I must highlight creativity in making the locations, creatures, bosses, and story, which punctuate the game experience even more.
I‚Äôm sure that if you give it a try, it will definitely find its special empty place in your heart, just as it did in mine. <3

Im not going to lie, the early game in hollow knight is... ambivalent. It can be very vague and a bit guide dependant (I had to use one for greenpath) however, I can't say much that is bad about the rest of the game, the story is great and the bosses are quite good (although some do lack many attacks and are gimmicky) the skill ceiling is extremely high and there are lots of challenges once you get good and after the first section of the game exploring is great and mostly obvious (if your looking). The aftergame content is also huge and great for achievement hunters, it actually requires skill unlike the dreaded staircase in DS3... I will say I do get input issues on this game though even with only my controller plugged in, however it is minor and only really affects top tier play (such as against the final and aftergame bosses)

While Hollow Knight may be a bit hard and unwelcoming for new players, its is an absolute masterpiece of a game that truly deserves the fame it has.
I really can't find any good complaints about it other than that your shade can be in a few awkward places and that the starting area is a bit grey/
Hollow knight also does one more thing amazingly:
It introduces mechanics at its own pace, gives the player time to breathe, doesn't heap on every mechanic at the same time.
The Tutorials are also pretty good, instead of just text, they put the player in an environment where they use the mechanic. along with some helpful, very short text guiding the player along.
And the Bosses! They may be a little hard, but the euphoria you receive after finally beating a hard boss you were struggling on is incomparable to any other joy in the game

The Mantis Lords were also really fun to fight
Stay hollow, knight.

Hollow Knight is SO far from the type of games I normally enjoy. Metroidvania, souls-like, and precision platforming are all things I tend to despise and ultimately rage quit. I have little patience for games that force you to grind the same thing over and over and over again. All that being said I was incredibly pleasantly surprised by this game. The learning curve is perfectly manageable. If I'm feeling like a little baby I can come back to a fight later or ignore it all together. I rarely need a break to cool my jets. The art style and sound design is beautiful, and the dialogue is short and sweet. No matter how good a game is, if it's ugly I lose interest, but that's far from an issue with the world of Hollow Knight.
So if you normally play these types of games, OBVIOUSLY you'll enjoy this game. But what I'm saying is if maybe you DON'T normally like these types of games, you should probably give Hollow Knight a try. You might surprise yourself. 
Admittedly, Silksong still looks far above my skill level, but who knows maybe by the end of this title I'll have newfound confidence. I may purchase it just to support Team Cherry. I love passionate devs and affordable games. Worth every penny.

Now that that's out of the way, hi :)
Uh, the game is fine, I guess. I hate how the progression works, and I hate how hard some of the bosses are simply because they throw enough things at you all at once. The game itself is great, the story is really intriguing, but god I hate how progression works. Not only is it the furthest thing from linear, but if you ever set the game down before the 10 hour mark, you're gonna spend the next session playing detective to try and figure out what you were doing, where you were going, and what the current goals are. I hate that this game doesn't have a proper quest system, nor does it really give you any hints.
I understand that half of the appeal is being able to go around and unlock new areas in previous areas you thought had already been explored, and while the environments look amazing and flow... fine, well, they get boring after you backtrack for the 40th time through them. It gets really repetitive, really fast. 
Despite all of that, though, I still really like the game. It's relatively simple in terms of mechanics, but it feels really nice, and while some of the bosses make me want to pull my hair out, most of them seem to be fair for their stage of progression (I still hate how progression is handled, though).

As a big fan of Metroidvanias and hard games such as the Dark Souls series, I felt that Hollow Knight would totally be up my alley - but whenever I saw a clip of gameplay I never got excited, so I didn't purchase it. With the release of Silksong and a nice sale, I felt I should finally give it a chance.
I have put in about 9 hours now, and I'm not sure if I'm going to continue playing, as the game doesn't really feel that engaging to me.
EDIT: I have finished the game after about 22 hours of playing, and my earlier assessment remains mostly unchanged.


The Negatives:

- The gameplay feels incredibly slow and boring before you get the Dash ability. In the early game, you can do a grand total of three things: walk, slash, jump. No ranged options, dodging, blocking, parrying, or even crouching. Consquently, combat also feels really limited and boring, and this barely changes with the few combat-relevant abilities you subsequently gain. Even towards the end of the game, I never felt that combat was interesting. Another reason for this shortcoming is that:

- Enemies aren't very engaging, and the vast majority of them uses the grand strategy of running into the player character. After some time playing I mostly tried to avoid combat because it's just tedious.

- The environments are visually beautiful, but not very interesting to navigate through; the different biomes all feel pretty much the same. For example, Greenpath looks very different compared to The Crossroads, but it doesn't _feel_ different and it doesn't play different: it's all platforms with pits.
I also kind of stopped looking for secret passages, because there's rarely anything of interest to find: at best, you'll be rewarded with a bit of money or a cryptic two-liner of lore. The truly relevant stuff such as new charms is usually hidden in plain sight. Related point:

- The environmental / jump & run challenges don't work well with the rest of the game. For example, approaching the City of Tears requires the player to do a number of tricky jumps/dashes, and it's designed well. However, failure is punished with HP loss, and there's not a lot of HP to go around. Consequence: instead of being able to keep trying, the player has to turn around and grind enemies for HP (or die and run all the way back from the last bench).
On the one hand, I feel that Hollow Knight could've used more such challenges, and I found the existing ones more engaging than combat; on the other hand, such gameplay lends itself to a game which is more lenient with its challenge (e.g. in 2D Metroid games failure in jump & run segments is often punished just with wasted time, or if HP is lost it is not a significant portion of overall HP).

- The game requires a lot of backtracking. Fast travel points are few and far between, and the world is clearly set up in a way that requires the player to return to previous areas a lot - which sucks, because most areas are barely interesting when you pass them the first time. This also makes enemies & environments appear even more boring, because you are constantly forced to cross sections you'be been in before again and again.

- The map system is dumb. I have to find an NPC in a new area before I can use the map? After I have purchased every single item the mapmaker shop offers, my character can't map on his own in a new area? What nonsense is this? What gameplay benefit is this supposed to achieve?


The Positives:

- Somewhat a matter of taste, but the difficulty feels well-balanced to me; So far, I wouldn't mind if the game was more difficult. The system of gathering Soul to power both HP recovery and abilities is clever.

- NPCs and their dialogues, and the lore in general, is great.

- Charms offer many interesting options for character building.

- Snappy and precise controls.


Toss-up:

- Music: I'll happily admit that the music is atmospheric, and it fits the game well, but... I can't say I feel it is outstanding.


CONCLUSION:
I don't think Hollow Knight is a bad game, and I can absolutely see why people enjoy it. But if I had to rate it based on my gameplay experience so far, I'd probably give it a 6 or perhaps 7 out of 10. I simply don't see the masterpiece it has been hailed as, and in all honesty, I'd rather play any of the Castlevanias or 2D Metroids instead. As such, I wouldn't recommend Hollow Knight to friends... hence my 'not recommended' rating.

It's been quite some time since I first played this game, but every time I open this game back up again I am astounded by its beauty, its wonderfully heartbreaking story, its music, boss design, exploration, literally everything about this game is fantastic. I had never played a metroidvania before, and was not used the the gameplay, and it took a while to get good. 
One of the things I do remember from my first playthrough was getting destroyed by the mantis lords a few too many times than I'd like to admit (granted, I had only been playing for 2-3 hours, so it wasn't like I was good yet), and eventually beating them and feeling so incredibly proud of myself. Other highlights from my first playthrough include bawling my eyes out at the ending [spoiler]when the hollow knight starts stabbing himself[/spoiler], ragequitting in the white palace because I suck(ed) at platforming, and thinking grey prince zote's intro is comedic gold. And then there's the music. Boy, is there music.
Some people think it's weird to listen to video game OSTs on a regular basis whenever you are not playing the game and listening to the music in the game. Those people are missing out on one of the greatest musical scores of all time. Christopher Larkin absolutely nailed the Hollow Knight soundtrack. Every track is so fitting, so perfect, so moving and beautiful. Queen's Gardens, Reflection, and Greenpath are what I wake up to every day, and starting my day with wonderful memories of Hallownest and its beauty makes waking up so much easier. It's serenity embodied, and it's enough to make a grown man cry. And then there are tracks like Sealed Vessel. The Grimm Troupe. Nightmare King. Pure Vessel. Holy shit are these bangers. The difficulty of these fights (I guess this only applies to Pure Vessel and NKG) matched with their music makes them all the more memorable. Pure Vessel's somber, slowly building theme is perfect for his lore and the sheer AURA in the fight entrance the first time, it all just fits so well. Same goes for NKG, god DAMN I struggled with that boss fight but the music and the precision made it feel like a dance to the death, jetstream sam style. Every move, every swing, every dodge mattered. Did I mention I love this game?
Hollow Knight has brought me an immense amount of joy over the 100 hours I've played, and the few years I've owned it, and I am proud to say that it is hands-down the best video game I have ever played and one of the best video games ever developed. I would give anything to erase my memory and travel through the ruins of Hallownest for the first time again. To experience the choral part of the City of Tears OST while looking out the window besides Quirrel on the bench, to the smile that crosses my face every time I free a grub and hear the adorable sound they make, to the tragic lore of the fall of Hallownest and the efforts to save it, Hollow Knight has made me feel things I never thought a video game could make me feel. I truly believe that this is the most enjoyment I've ever gotten for 15 bucks I think I got this game for? What a steal. Anyways, stop reading this review and go buy the damn game. If you want to get lost in the best video game lore ever made while playing a platformer where you fight silly little bugs (and later god), Hollow Knight is for you.

My dear friend gave me this game years ago. I never really got into it until Silksong was days away, or already came out. The gameplay, art, music, all mastercrafted. 10/10 favourite game of all time. Would highly recommend to anyone who's willing to commit a lot of time and effort into playing a video game.
