Overall an excellent game! Challenging, beautiful art and environments, great atmosphere, well made progression, lots of content, nice music, well-priced.

Some cons (mostly minor) are that the game has huge and complex zones with plenty of backtracking. Fast travel is not good enough, so you'll end up manually going through majority of the zones and you'll waste a lot of time. Some zones are impossible to go through until you find a certain item, but most of the times you wouldn't know if the newly acquired item unlocked something or where to use it, so you'll have to either explore everything again or simply search for a guide online (which I ended up doing at some point, because there's was just too much searching for where to go). Also your map has no indicator for your current position until you sacrifice an item slot and a bit of your personal power. It felt really bad to downgrade my character, but unless you know the whole map by heart, you'll need to have an indicator.

Its an enjoyable game but I feel like its also something more of an "experience". To me it doesn't really stand out a lot against other Metroidvania games like Ori, Bloodstained, Momodora or Ender Lilies. Given that the game itself doesn't really have any weak points though, it does make for a good gateway into the genre.

The environments, enemies, art and sound direction are all fairly nice. The story is presented in a breadcrumb fashion, so that might be hit or miss depending on if that's your sort of thing.

Edit: I think I was a bit too harsh with my phrasing on the initial review, while I still stand by the game not excelling at aspects, I think its overall a very good complete package. Its very consistent in its presentation, escalation and gameplay without any large spikes or jumps. Everything progresses naturally so its a smooth ride from start to finish. Due to this, while I think something like the above titles are better "games", Hollow Knight is both a better "experience" and package. I also feel that this is true of Silksong. Silksong is a stronger "game" while Hollow Knight is a better "experience".

I first bought Hollow Knight for PS4 about 7-6 years ago and quickly got bored of it in an hour or two, because i didn't know what to do and were just wandering in forgotten crossroads aimlessly. This time when I didn't know what to do, I just opened a Steam guide to know what i should do next.

Hollow Knight was a fairly easy game overall, with a few difficulty increases in optional bosses, some of which I haven't even beaten yet. It offers at least a couple dozen hours of gameplay, with plenty more if you explore everything and try getting every achievement. 

Overall amazing game, great soundtracks/music, enjoyable boss fights, smooth movement, nice graphics, good lore, and well-made NPCs.
Absolutely would recommend buying Hollow Knight if you're considering it, especially if it's on sale.

This game fully deserves most of the praise it gets. Art style, combat, music, enemy variety, boss design, difficulty, level design, exploration, it's all done really well.

But the excessive backtracking just completely kills the whole experience.

Metroidvanias are all about unlocking new movement abilities, and then going back to the areas you've already explored and being able to access new paths that were previously inaccessible. This is a key part of their progressions systems and one of the most satisfying things about them.

In Hollow Knight, this is the worst part of the game because fast travel is extremely limited and the levels are long and the movement somewhat slow. Backtracking to a previously explored area can easily take 10-15 minutes. And you can easily die along the way and have to re-backtrack from the last bench (Dark Souls-like checkpoint) you rested at.

Then, once you've done whatever it is that you went back there for, you now have to make the round trip. 

The only saving grace is that you can quit out to the main menu and load back into the game, and this will teleport you back to the last bench you used. But you can't teleport between benches without mods, so you'll probably still have to backtrack for 5-10 minutes to get to one of the very rare fast travel stations. 

Also, having to quit out to the main menu so often destroys the immersion.  

Backtracking isn't an accidental problem, either. The game deliberately adds as much of it as possible. Various shopkeepers   and key NPCs are located far from fast travel stations to force you to backtrack even more. The only vendor that buys vendor trash requires backtracking to get to, and accompanies every single generic sale with boring dialogue, for no reason whatsoever. Why is this the case? Why isn't this vendor just located in the main hub town? Why can't you just bulk-sell stuff to him? 

None of this is challenging or fun. The game is just designed to waste your time.

I really liked Hollow Knight at first, but the backtracking just slowly grinded me down. 

Eventually, after backtracking for 10+ minutes to kill an optional boss, I looked at the map and the looooooong trip back, and I just thought "nah, I'm, good".

[b]TL;DR[/b]
A beautiful and mysterious world buried under layers of deliberate inconvenience. Every design choice seems to scream: ‚ÄúWhat if we made this more confusing?‚Äù Gorgeous, but exhausting.

[h3]Pros[/h3]

+ Beautiful world, stunning art direction, great atmosphere.
+ Music and sound design are absolutely top-notch.
+ Boss fights are intense and fair ‚Äî in theory.
+ The lore is deep and intriguing ‚Äî once you give up and watch it explained on YouTube.

[h3]Cons[/h3]

[b]Navigation & Map Design[/b]
- Biomes look drastically different from each other, but rooms within the same biome all look the same.
- Corridors and intersections lack distinct landmarks ‚Äî making it nearly impossible to remember where each path leads.
- Yes, there are signs pointing to benches or cities, but they form long chains of arrows that don‚Äôt actually help you remember anything.
- The world is chopped into small rooms, which only adds to the confusion. Seamless travel could‚Äôve helped navigation, but for some reason, the developers decided to stick with room-based transitions that make everything feel disjointed.

The map is another story altogether:
- You only get a map of a region if you find the cartographer ‚Äî who somehow teleports ahead of you even if you run in a straight line. And the cartographer makes only half of the map; the other part you fill in yourself, which makes you a cartographer as well. But for some artificial reason, you can map only some rooms while relying on him for others. It makes no sense!
- To see your position on the map, you must equip a compass charm that takes up a precious combat slot. So you end up juggling this charm on before exploring and off before a boss fight ‚Äî adding nothing of value to the experience, only annoyance.
- Automatic map markers are often placed right on top of passages, hiding important paths behind icons.
- Custom markers are nearly useless ‚Äî you get four bleak colors, no text, and no way to remember what each one means.

[b]Boss Fights & Repetition[/b]
- Bosses are tough, fair, and often fun. The real problem is the [b]repetition[/b]. You‚Äôll die, then spend several minutes running the same path to that boss again. Over. And over. And over. It feels like the devs thought: ‚ÄúWhat if we made players repeat the same corridor fifty times to appreciate the atmosphere?‚Äù
- The final boss is especially exhausting: beat Boss A, then Boss B, then Boss B again, then Boss B again ‚Äî and every time you die, you restart from the very beginning. It‚Äôs not that hard ‚Äî it‚Äôs just artificially punishing, and quickly becomes dull and frustrating.

[b]Story & Lore[/b]
- The world itself is beautiful, melancholic, and full of potential. But the story is told through fragments and vague, disconnected lines.
- Most NPCs speak in riddles that sound deep but add nothing of actual meaning. By the twentieth cryptic monologue, it started feeling like they were just wasting my time on purpose. I love collecting lore and piecing together a story, but here it felt like trying to assemble a puzzle with half the pieces missing and no picture on the box. In the end, I learned the story from YouTube ‚Äî not from the game itself.

[b]General Design Philosophy[/b]
- Everything in Hollow Knight feels like it was made [b]confusing for the sake of confusion[/b] and [b]inconvenient for the sake of inconvenience[/b]. UI, navigation, map, dialogue ‚Äî every system seems to go out of its way to test your patience. It‚Äôs not the difficulty that frustrates ‚Äî it‚Äôs the deliberate, artificial friction built into everything.
The devs managed to balance irritation so precisely that it somehow attracted a cult of masochists defending it.

[b]Controller Hell[/b]
- Downward slash on a controller is nearly impossible to perform consistently.
- Dash on a squeaky trigger gets old fast.
- Charging an attack and jumping can‚Äôt be done together (both actions require the right thumb).
- After playing through about 80% of the game, I had to completely relearn everything on keyboard ‚Äî which is its own form of pain.
The fact that the game officially claims ‚Äúcontroller supported‚Äù feels misleading. They might as well write:
‚ÄúYou can technically play with a controller, but good luck trying to do pogo attacks!‚Äù

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
Hollow Knight is breathtaking to look at, haunting to listen to, and conceptually brilliant.
But underneath that, it‚Äôs a maze of frustration ‚Äî a game that constantly reminds you how much smoother and more enjoyable it [i]could‚Äôve been[/i].
It‚Äôs not a ‚Äúsoulslike challenge‚Äù; it‚Äôs a [b]user experience horror[/b].

Overrated. I bought this game just to see what all the hype is about. I finished the Ori series a few years ago and I don't mind playing side-scrolling platforming games.

The mechanics are simple and straightforward. But it suffers from the same issue I have with the Dark Souls games -- forced tediousness. Everytime you die you are forced to walk the through same tedious (and often boring) path over and over again just to recover your money. 

I don't mind hard games. I've played Sekiro countless times. I played Doom Eternal in hardest difficulty countless times. What I hate are TEDIOUS games -- games that FORCE you to suffer repetition for no reason other than because the devs want you to punish you with boredom because of your mistakes.

Did you just die from a boss? Well tough luck, you have to travel 100km up and down the same path just to recover your ghost and the money it's carrying. Do you keep dying from the spikes on the wall because you can't get the platforming down? Well tough luck, you will again have to travel 100km up and down the same boring path just to repeat that tedious platforming challenge.

The art style is also overrated. I don't feel anything for the hand-drawn cartoon style in the same way I felt love for Ori's art style. I don't mind it, I just don't feel anything for it.

Lastly the story is also overrated. It again borrows a lot of its style from the Dark Souls series -- cryptic and ambiguous. 8 hours in and I only have the faintest idea of what my character's goal is. Compare that with the Ori series: Straight away you are given the premise, and you as the player know exactly what the conflict is, and what your grand overarching goal is. It's just a matter of achieving that goal.

Ori was the better game. Both Ori 1 and 2 were excellent in terms of gameplay, art style, and story telling.
Hollow Knight is just not for me.

Wasn't really sure what to expect but I had heard good things. Absolutely BLOWN AWAY by the creativity and progression scaling. Every upgrade feels like you earn it, every rest point feels like you earn it. This is a MUST play if you enjoy platformers of any kind. 10/10

Hollow Knight's world is deep and rich and meticulously designed, but thing that really makes the game sing is the way the movement feels. Its snappy and responsive, super precise and yet so smooth. One action flows into the next so seamlessly it's really easy to enter into a flow state. The wall jump, dash, double jump, and pogo all feel perfect, and chaining them together makes for some absolutely delicious platforming, and truly great combat. It is a game where I do not mind long traversal times between locations because the moment-to-moment gameplay is just sublime.

At its core, Hollow Knight is a Metroidvania where you don't lose all your exploration progress if you die. But what makes it great is how tight the controls are - you have so much precision about where you're going, how to avoid attacks, and everything.

Fair warning, it's not the easiest game. But I can think of only one part which is both required and seemed a little too tough for when it pops up - and even then you can go off and explore for damage and ability upgrades if you want to, the game's pretty open as to where you can go after you get a couple of movement upgrades.

Top marks, now to take a break before moving on to Silksong!

This was my first Metroidvania game I ever played. It always had a special place in my heart, but it wasn't until my second playthrough 5 years later that I realised just how incredible this game really is. 
I played Silksong right after playing this game for the 2nd time and I will say, even though Silksong improves upon essentially everything, this is its own game that shines more then most games I have ever played.
Similar to my Silksong review, the world, music, bosses, combat, just the constant urge to want to keep exploring and discover more about Hallownest's deep lore and secrets. The game is one of the most backlogged games ever for a reason. I pray everyone gives this masterpiece a try and the chance to experience playing this game and Silksong back to back like I did, because it will forever be one of the most unforgettable franchises I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing and I want nothing more then for Team Cherry to keep hopefully providing.

I had the chance to play Hollow Knight for the first time in April 2024. I hadn‚Äôt watched any trailers and expected something like Ori mixed with Dark Souls ‚Äî and I fell in love within the first few hours.

Hollow Knight has it all: a perfect soundtrack, precise and satisfying movement, countless amazing boss fights, and a dark, mysterious world that keeps expanding the more you explore. The variety of biomes is incredible ‚Äî you lose count of how many there actually are. Every essential feature you could hope for exists in the game, and you‚Äôll discover them naturally as you explore the world with both eyes open (which also helps you appreciate just how beautiful this game truly is).

I‚Äôve never played another game with such rewarding hidden locations. Thanks to its outstanding soundtrack and art direction, I never hesitated to revisit previous areas. Many boss fights require sharp platforming and quick reactions, which makes every victory even more satisfying.

The base game alone is a 10/10, and the three free DLCs elevate it even further. My only small criticisms are that some things are hidden too well ‚Äî you might miss the PoP, the entrance to the third DLC, or even certain charms.

Hollow Knight is one of my favorite games of all time, and I haven‚Äôt even started talking about the lore, the NPCs, their unique sound effects, or the questlines. It‚Äôs a game that brings together everything I love: Metroidvania exploration, diverse biomes, quirky animal-like NPCs, epic boss battles, a detailed bestiary, a rich orchestral soundtrack, and a dark, mysterious world with a Souls-like story quietly running in the background.

I honestly can‚Äôt recommend any game more than this!

Very atmospheric game. Some areas, especially City of Tears have spellbound me with music and vibes. Game progression is well made, first you barely survive in this world but slowly your nail gets stronger, you learn new moving and attacking skills eventually becoming the killing machine of Hallownest. Bosses are different. Some hold special place in my heart (Mantis Lords, Dung Defender, Hollow Knight, 
[spoiler]Radiance[/spoiler] ) because of how fun their fights are and some I just want to forget, luckily there are very few of bad bosses. 

Lore and story seem complex at first but are in fact quite simple, even if you didn't understand everything in game, you can watch any good video on youtube. Characters, despite quite small amount of dialogues, are really memorable since they are really well written. I love Quirrel and Hornet, those, who help you on your way, Sly, who is pretty interesting and you will find out why, and of course I won't forget Cornifer, Iselda, Bretta, Zote and others you meet.

Hollow Knight is one of those rare games that feels handcrafted with love in every pixel. The world of Hallownest is vast, mysterious, and melancholy ‚Äî filled with quiet stories and secrets waiting to be discovered.

The combat is precise and satisfying, the art direction is stunning, and the soundtrack perfectly captures the game‚Äôs somber tone. It never holds your hand, but rewards exploration and perseverance in a way few games manage.

Pros:

- Gorgeous hand-drawn art
- Deep, challenging combat
- Atmospheric world design
- Incredible soundtrack
- Constant sense of discovery

Cons:
- You‚Äôll die a lot (but you‚Äôll learn from it)
- You may get lost (often)

If you love exploration, challenge, and quiet storytelling, Hollow Knight isn‚Äôt just a game ‚Äî it‚Äôs an experience.
Best game I‚Äôve ever played, if you‚Äôre questioning whether to get it or not, GET IT NOW!

The fact that Hollow Knight has held up it's popularity for so many years goes to show how good this game is. It is a metroidvania style game, with fun combat and a hand drawn art style, with a large map to explore, abilities to unlock, and secrets to uncover.

The game features a small but mighty bug warrior who returns to a forgotten and crumbling kingdom below the surface to learn about his past. As I mentioned, it was a very large world to explore. With several different and unique areas to find, there was always something new to do or discover. I also liked how unique every area was, ranging from lush gardens to desolate lands below the ground to forgotten cities, making each area a memorable experience. There also is a wide variety of enemies to fight, with each of them having different attacks, movements, and skills, making you have to constantly adapt to what environment you're in. The bosses were also very fun, with each having it's own abilities and movements. There also are a ton of bosses in Hollow Knight, so there will always be somebody new to fight. There is just so much unique and exciting content, the game never feels stale.

I also just want to mention how amazing the music was. Every track was incredible, complimenting the locations and events in which they are played in like I have never seen before in a video game. The art style also complimented the overall mood of the game so well, with it's hand drawn style and detailed backgrounds. I also liked the charming characters, who all have their own personalities and stories. Since the lands of Hallownest are mostly devoid of non-hostile life, It was very fun encountering a new character, and they all added a little life into the empty lands. They also did such a good job on the secrets, with all of them being rewarding and fun to uncover. The game also gives you little guidance on what to do. This is actually a good thing because the game is hard enough that you feel accomplished when you discover something new, but not hard enough that you constantly need to look up tutorials on what to do. The same can be said about the difficulty. It's hard enough to be a "hard game" and make you feel prideful in your achievements, but not hard enough that you want to punch a hole in your monitor.

If I had to say 1 bad thing about Hollow Knight, it would be how the story felt slightly obscure and hard to comprehend, and you have to piece it together yourself. Good thing that the story is not really needed to enjoy the game.

So in short, Hollow Knight is a masterpiece of video games, and I highly recommend to most people. If you are wondering if you'll get your moneys worth from this game, trust me you will. It almost feels wrong to be paying only $15 for this incredible game. This has to be one of, if not the easiest 10/10 I have ever given to a game.

Hollow Knight has so many things going for it. The art style, animations and the soundtrack are beautiful. The world is immersive and the story is engaging. Input is overall very responsive and the gameplay and movement are pretty fluid. I love exploring the map. 

Yet, with all that said, I simply don't enjoy this game. Getting through some sections feels like a chore. Personally, I don't find the combat satisfying and I haven't enjoyed a single boss fight. I don't mind difficult games and consider myself fairly competent at them, but I struggle with the combat in this game because I simply don't find it fun. I haven't struggled too much with the corpse runs like some other players, but that is also a pretty annoying mechanic for someone who has limited time to put into playing a game. I still think this game might be worth a try if you enjoy metroidvania style games, but don't assume you'll love it because you liked Ori or even Cuphead for the matter. I really wish I liked this game more considering the time I've put into it already.
BEST GAME EVER!!!!!!!!!!!! if you wanna play it then play till hornet to see if you like the game DONT QUIT IN CROSSROADS!!!!!!!!!
Perfect game
the perfect game. allows for a challenge, while keeping the game relatively great.

Filling out the map and trying to get the next ability and the next one and the next one so you can explore a new area, to get a new thing, to explore another area that you wanted to get to earlier so you can save an adorable little grub. If that kind of addictive exploring is your thing, this is your game. However, it is hard imo. 

Game scared me off the first time because it seemed hard and unforgiving. [spoiler](I thought I permanently lost all my geo when I died.)[/spoiler]

I gave it another chance, struggled, got better, got through the first boss, second boss. One time I had to have my brother get me out of a difficult area because I was just sick of it. But I practised, got better, can now do those areas with ease, fought most of the most challenging bosses in the game, even did a no death run succesfully in the end, for a game I almost rage-quit because I thought the starting area was to hard for me already.

This game taught me that I can do difficult games, and I've since tried other games on harder settings. It taught me that a challenging difficulty in a game can be fun and fulfilling. Some optional bosses I had to return to a half year later becausu i couldn't do it at the time, but in the end I persevered. Now whenever I face a challenge, I know that I went from 'I can't do this game', to beating the  [spoiler]white palace and even path of pain later[/spoiler], to beating  [spoiler]the radiance[/spoiler], to beating  [spoiler]hollow knight on steel soul[/spoiler]. I can do so much that I once thought impossible. Truly a life-changing game for me. 

TLDR: Addictive metroidvenia, challenging but worth it

Play if you
- Like a challenge and have the time/patience to improve, or are already decent at this kind of game.
- Want a game with good artstyle, fun music, backtracking to re-explore areas in new fun ways

Do not play (or instead just watch a playthrough) if you:
- Aren't that skilled yet at these types of games and can't / don't want to learn. Which is perfectly fine :)
- Dislike challenging games

Having just finished the story for this game (true ending achieved), I must say I have mixed feelings about it.

I play as bug in a world of bugs and I have always known that "the only good bug is a dead bug". I love Starship Troopers and Helldivers so everything just felt wrong and out of place. I was so conflicted, it was like I was betraying everything I stood for. I was wondering "what am I doing here?" or "How can I bring myself to do this, to betray democracy and everything I stand for?" or even "Who am I?"

These questions haunted me for a good while but then I finally had the answer: I am a bug, yes, but here I am killing all the other bugs. I'm a traitor bug that found clarity and decided to destroy every last one of the other bugs! It was glorious! I had no more remorse about being a bug, now I could just kill them all freely.

I found an hunter, like myself, that gave me a journal which helped me compile information about the other bugs and as we all know "to fight the bug we must understand the bug". So I gathered information about the enemy and I went on a killing spree. I ended up finishing the journal and my mentor was proud of me. My mission was done. 

I killed every single bug there was! That is, except from one... 

Hornet, I will see you in Pharloom and you will not escape me this time.

[Significant end/post-game spoiler ahead!]
I don't think I've ever fallen in love with a game so quickly as with Hollow Knight. The combat, the music, the lore, the sound design, the bosses, the motifs, the areas, all of it.

The only thing I like less is how inconsequential the final boss(es) feel. Everything about them is so dramatic and screams that this is a grand finale, the zenith of your adventure. You defeat them, the cutscene plays, the credits roll and you're sent to a new main menu. You join back into your save and...nothing. It's like the fight never happened. You received nothing except a main menu background and an achievement, and the Infection is still rampant throughout Forgotten/Infected Crossroads.

Regardless, everything else this game has to offer more than makes up for this. Love this game, looking forward to trying Silksong.

This game is an open world game, so every direction is the 'right' direction. Also you can play for hours just grinding money and upgrading the character's skills and collecting charms. Or you can proceed with the story, you can easily get lost in the game but that makes it more fun, finding you way around the map and you get this really good feeling after killing a boss you spent hours on finding/killing. Would recommend, plus the story is interesting; doesn't take up much storage or money to download this. Edit: way bigger than i first thought, tons of mini, big bosses to drag you into the game; you can watch tutorials for the bosses or spend at least 2 hours to learn a boss's attack pattern and killing it. U can also replay the game as much as you want. Warning : you will get addicted to this.

Overall pretty good game, but its really challenging and the mechanics are hard to grasp.

If you want a game with rich lore, content, and challenging gameplay, this game is a must pick up. Unlike modern single player games that hold your hand to make you understand every mechanic or point you to the next plot for the story, Hollow Knight offers a balanced challenge between your hands and brains. The difficulty of bosses and parkour all depend on the players' playstyle and strategy, boss difficulty is unique per player. Similarly, the game is fully non-linear. You can go explore one area until you hit a roadblock and explore another, and so on. 

Overall, if you want a great single-player game with a good story and forgiving mechanics, this game is a must pick-up, especially considering the price is a really cheap bargain for the amount of content.

I absolutely love this game. I played it before on a friend's computer with my xbox account so I started anew with buying it here on Steam. The gameplay, the story, the graphics, EVERYTHING IS AMAZING. 10/10 will play for years to come. Will 100% buy Silksong after I finish this game.

I walked into this game with a certain idea of its story, but not much, assuming the simplistic forgotten crosswords was the tone for the whole game. That was the first of many mistakes I made. Instead, Hollow Knight is a journey through every environment possible, every nook and crevice hiding a secret or more lore. It's visuals and soundtrack are what transport you into that little bug traversing a lost kingdom, and boy, did I love being that bug. Never before has every death felt like it counted towards my progress, inching my way through a bosses health bar till I finally managed to best it. All in all, a game I would come back to from time to time just to experience what it feels like to play the perfect metroidvania, and die multiple times in the process.

[b]Pros:[/b]
-Amazing metroidvania-style gameplay
-Rewarding exploration
-Rewarding progression system
-Free DLC added to base game
-Fun challenges and achievements
-High replay value
-Deep lore with variety of methods of storytelling to communicate it
-Memorable NPCs
-Gorgeous artwork and soundtrack

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Input controls can be imprecise at times, leading to problems in precision platforming sections
-Some bosses have a frustrating RNG element to them (Looking at you, Grey Prince Zote)

[b]Overall:[/b] You know what this game is. I don't even know why I'm reviewing it except I felt like it needed to be praised one more time. Hollow Knight is one of those generational gaming experiences, at least it has been for me. There's a lot of cookie cutter nonsense out there, and on the surface, having one more side scrolling metroidvania definitely sounds boring. But Team Cherry did it flawlessly, and made the world and game with obvious care and love.

Any complaints I have are minor. The game rewards exploration and has fun challenges, not all of which lead to any substantial reward or have an achievement attached. The game is just fun to play, and rewards you for playing it. It's fantastic game design, and I loved the little easter eggs scattered throughout the game waiting to be discovered.

If you haven't tried this, and you're here because everyone is hyped about Silksong, you owe it to yourself to play this game. For me, I'm off to Silksong now that I've enjoyed my time here.

[b]Bottom Line:[/b] Obvious recommend

Hollow Knight: An Indie Masterpiece

Hollow Knight is a Metroidvania ‚Äî a genre built around exploration, backtracking, and unlocking new paths through new abilities. It‚Äôs not flashy, it doesn‚Äôt hold your hand, and the gameplay is surprisingly simple. You‚Äôre just a tiny bug with a nail. Yet, through that simplicity, the game shines brighter than most AAA titles. It‚Äôs pure, precise platforming action that rewards patience and mastery.

The presentation is phenomenal. The art style feels like Tim Burton meets a Saturday morning cartoon ‚Äî dark but charming, creepy but beautiful. The music and sound design sell the atmosphere perfectly, making the world of Hallownest feel alive and haunting.

Gameplay evolves as you progress. New movement abilities like the dash and double jump turn exploration into fast-paced platforming challenges, and the Charm system adds fun layers of customization. Geo management ‚Äî your currency for upgrades, charms, and maps ‚Äî encourages careful spending and even risk-taking when you have to retrieve it after dying.

Of course, it‚Äôs not perfect. The backtracking can get exhausting, the lack of clear direction can frustrate, and early progression feels punishing for newcomers. The story is vague and cryptic, told in that ‚ÄúFromSoftware‚Äù style where half the mystery is figuring out what‚Äôs going on. Boss runs can be tedious due to long treks between save points, and the difficulty curve isn‚Äôt always even.

But even with its flaws, Hollow Knight is a masterpiece. It doesn‚Äôt reinvent its genre ‚Äî it makes it feel brand new. From a three-person indie team, this level of polish, atmosphere, and heart is unbelievable. In a world full of bloated AAA games, Hollow Knight reminds me what makes video games special.

Final Verdict: 9/10 ‚Äì A haunting, challenging, beautiful journey worth every swing of the nail.

On the surface, this game is about exploration. That being said, you'll get VERY lost along the way, but also discover lots of secrets. The game doesn't force you to do anything except decide where to go and what to do; the rest is up to you, including piecing together the story of the "Hollownest," which is the name for the world you're exploring. As usual with platform/metroidvania games, this game comes with its frustrations and difficult boss fights, but it's quite compelling nonetheless.

I enjoyed Hollow Knight when it released back in 2018, and I enjoyed playing through the main game again. I would fully recommend it if you play that and end it there. Anything beyond that, I wouldn't recommend. Some of the end-game levels are so frustrating in a way that feels unfamiliar with the design in the rest of the game. These issues are pretty much non-existent in Silksong. 

I would say the end parts of Hollow Knight, when compared to Silksong, really go to show the growth of Team Cherry's map design skills over the past 7 years since the game released.

After taking a break for years and eventually coming back and restarting my playthrough, Hollow Knight deserves all the praise that it receives. Very very fluid gameplay with no input delay, the control you feel over your actions feels just as satisfying as it does frustrating at times. 

Quite rewarding as most souls-likes should be. The only critique I have is a mistake of my own; not properly utilizing map markers to signify where I needed to backtrack once I unlocked later abilities that opened new pathways.

The art style, music, atmosphere, everything about this game is beautiful. Rightfully deserves its place in the Indie Hall of Fame.

It's really annoying to have to go into a new section blind to find the map, and if you die along the way you lose all of your geos. A ghost tries to attack you, so I usually lose alot of health trying to skirt by or I'll try to find another route around. I find myself playing with google images open so I can figure out where to go since I can never accumulate enough money to afford the stags or maps that I've found thus far. 

At review time, I only have the map for the forgotten crossroads, have visited four out of the five areas that surround it, and have only defeated the main boss in FC, and Hornet in the Green Path. By my calculations, I've lost around 4000 geos from dying so much.

Maybe if they implemented something where you didn't lose money forever I'd have more patience for the game. I enjoy Metrovanias, and I thought I'd get further here, but right now, no.

This game is absolutely glorious. I'm speechless about its story and how it connects the pieces of the lore, one by one, until the very end. The gameplay, as well as the soundtrack, is absolutely gorgeous. Even the NPCs are well-made and very attractive. Without saying too much, this is one of the best games I've ever played in my life, and it has inspired me to look for other Metroidvania games, since this was my first one.

The first game I've played that is like this. The art style is very cozy and the background elements feel in place with the interactable objects which is something I think a lot of games struggle with. The map systems are challenging for sure, but once you get used to the controls its worth it. I put 54 hours into my first play through and I feel like there is still a lot of content I could explore on a second run. For the price and the care put in, I'd say this is a lovely game for anyone that likes platformer games.

I have never really played any games like this. Hollow Knight was my introduction, and I don't think I could have picked a better one. The art is absolutely beautiful. If I die in stupid ways, it's because I'm too busy appreciating the art.

The gameplay follows a very natural flow, and whenever I have to backtrack, it doesn't feel as annoying as it did in Metroid. (Probably the only game like Hollow Knight I've ever played.) The characters are all really fun and interesting, but none as much as the Might Zote, who is the best character in the game, despite what many people would have you believe.

I love the way the movement feels. I feel totally in control of my character, and it contributes to why I don't have any issue with the difficulty: if I die, I know what I did wrong, and I feel totally in control of doing better. The game doesn't feel unfair, just challenging, and I really like that.

Currently working on p5, but it'll probably be a while until I succeed. I will go for 112%. Will probably try to get all achievements, too. I rarely find the motivation to go all the way with large games like this, but Hollow Knight is just that good.

If you love exploring other kinds of narratives. Of you enjoy exploring. If you want a challenge. If you want to fight hard bosses. If any of this applies to you, this is your game. 

A little piece of hope among a cosmos of darkness. That's what hollow knight is about, and how it feels to play it. I've finished it around 5 times and I have never get tiered of it. I've been getting better, playing better, fighting harder challenges. I'm not a particularly good player, but this game made want to be better. Today I have got all achievements. And It was worth every second of it.

The first time I played this game I dropped it after a few hours and didn't touch it for a year. But after picking it up again something was different and I got it to 112%.
I think the hardest part was getting a feeling for this game, at least for me. The game dropped you into a strange and hostile world, only telling you the controls, the rest is up to you. I had big problems with the map itself, didn't really know what to do and where to go. Was the main reason I quit. But after discovering more and more, something clicked. It was really fun getting new abilities, so you can progress somewhere else. This game does that pretty well, after a while you always have a hinge what to do next. 
Combat and parkour is fun. Love the hand drawn world, lots of love was put into this. Also the soundtrack is a big plus.

The game has a great atmosphere. Second to none, really. Coming back to this from Silksong, I think Hollow Knight stands on its own and still provides a unique experience compared to its sequel.
What was once a real challenge for me as a teenager has become oddly cozy after Silksong. It's an odd feeling, and very rewarding. Like, "Oh! There was only two waves of common enemies! How sweet."
Except The Watchers. Awful, awful boss fight. There's like, one too many Watchers. Even after the little secret to reduce the numbers. But it did teach me to not be so frugal with special attacks, so I suppose... that's good game design?

It took me a long time to get to play this game, as it was always something I've heard about and just never gave it any thought. Having a bad habit of starting new games and never finishing them also came into play. I enjoy metroidvanias and I do enjoy some toughness in games, like most souls-like games. When the marriage of those two things are pretty much the center of this game has made quite the experience. There are games that I like to go back to, to either keep some of my skills relevant and just for the love of playing them, Hollow Knight will be counted in one of those games. 

In other words, as a long time person who plays games, I simply love playing this game. The characters, lore, music and artistry: I love them all. It deserves the praise that it gets and more.

I have a bad habit of putting games down after a while. Even if I like the game and even if I have made decent progress in it. Hollow Knight was one such game. It made a solid impression on me but after a couple of bosses I put the game down in favor of some life obligations. When I got back into gaming, didnt go back to Hollow Knight until I heard about the hype for Silksong recently. 

I booted it back up and wow, its one of the best in the 2d-mele-platformer-darksouls-like-metroidvania genre. Only No Nine Sols that I played on Game Pass recently is as good or better but then again its more inspired from Sekiro's deflect mechanic and they are building on the shoulders of giants like Team Cherry that have blazed a trail in this genre and indie space!

Full marks from me!

Awesome design, sounds, music, the world overall is very enjoyable to look and listen, the atmosphere created by the game is awesome.

However i didn't like combat at all, and since it takes 70% of the game if not more, 
the game left me with negative emotions.

Majority of damage and deaths in this game feels unfair. One of examples is when one certain boss had little summons spawning, and they were the same color as background of the arena. But also they could spawn near you or even inside you, which makes you take damage just because you are unlucky. Also you could see many negative reviews about primal aspid, which covers a lot of screen with its attack and just super hard to dodge because of it, especially when the arena is very limited. There is much more such moments that feel unfair and i don't find this kind of challenge satisfying, its more like frustrating.

Also the game felt like its lacking some combat options, you only have a nail, [spoiler]dash, double jump and 3 spells or so, which are practically the same, differing only in the direction of attack, not doing any effect beside damage and pushing enemy away[/spoiler] so at one point i felt like bosses can do a lot of staff, damage me in a countless ways possible, and i can just... well strike with a nail that's all. Oh and use a [spoiler]spell [/spoiler] which does some damage, but uses soul, so you sacrifice your healing potential. Charms system is good, but it doesn't change gameplay much, sometimes is just gives a small buff which could improve your quality of life, but your combat cycle won't change anyway.

And of course, the amount of backtracking is really big, the game has fast travel system, but it doesn't cover all the parts of a map, just some of them, so you gotta run around the map just to find some path you couldn't unlock until now. Or find some item you couldn't use until now. Or run to the boss which just killed you. By the way there is an [spoiler]ability which allows you to travel to the one location you set yourself, but you get it really late into the game and it didn't feel like i saved much time with it[/spoiler]

And that brings to the next problem, these paths aren't marked on the map. Lets say you found a path you can't reach due to lacking some item, and you have to return here later. The problem is that on the map it will look like you didn't go that way. So if you made some pause between your gaming sessions, you will need to remember which paths are locked, and which ones you just haven't visited because you had crossroad and chose to go another path. To solve this issue partially developers let you buy some pins, which serve like a markers you can set on map, but i don't understand why they are not available right away, and must be purchased from some npc, and why it cannot be done automatically, since some ways obviously require some certain item and absolutely cannot be accessed without it.

So overall i recommend to play this game and see if you like it yourself, and if you find the combat unsatisfying just like i did, just go finish only necessary bosses, since they are much easier than optional ones.

Anyway gonna hop on silksong, i hope its better.

First Metroidvania game I‚Äôve ever played, and I had never touched difficult games before. But thanks to Hollow Knight, I‚Äôve entered the world of souls-like games. It‚Äôs really hard, and I loved it so much that I went for the platinum trophy (some achievements, especially P5, are insanely difficult).

At the beginning, the game feels a bit empty ‚Äî the world is desolate and there aren‚Äôt many mechanics. But as you keep exploring, you discover the true face of this masterpiece.

This game isn‚Äôt for baby girls, but if you want to take it slow, not everything and not every boss is mandatory. The game just throws you in with a huge map to explore and lets you figure things out on your own, with very few explanations ‚Äî and that‚Äôs part of its beauty.

While playing, I used a lot of guides, but that‚Äôs not necessary at all ‚Äî it just makes things a bit easier.
The story is really amazing: you are a knight who must save a fallen kingdom from an infection. Unfortunately, the game doesn‚Äôt explain much about the lore, so you might need to watch some videos to fully understand it.

Despite its difficulty, the game rarely feels repetitive, and there‚Äôs a ton of content to enjoy. For the price it asks, it‚Äôs absolutely incredible.

In conclusion, Hollow Knight is a truly fantastic game.
The graphics and environments are stunning, the music is great, and the boss mechanics are simply brilliant.
Highly recommended for those who love exploration, tough challenges, and breathtaking art¬†and¬†atmosphere.

Play literally any other metroidvania game.

While the game is alright and perfectly playable, it's also an endless exercise in frustration. It feels like someone decided to make the most irritating game possible. My main impression of the game so far is just that it's all friction, zero payoff.

If you're really really REALLY interested in the game then sure, go for it, play it. But you're honestly just way better off playing one of the many other games in the genre that actually respects the player.

This game pretty much has it all:
Great world design, awesome lore, satisfying combat, good difficulty curve, fun bosses, beautiful art direction

I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve had this much fun in a video game in a while. This game gets straight to the point unlike a lot of games these days.

The amount of quality content you get for the price is insane. I‚Äôve played this game for 60+ hours now at the time of writing and there‚Äôs still more content left after I got 103%. 

I am excited to check out Silksong next!
